It has the following objective(s): The aim of this grant is to increase the participation, success and graduation rates of disadvantaged students in general. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: South Africa
heading: NATIONAL INTEGRATED CYBER-INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEM
content: South Africa's NATIONAL INTEGRATED CYBER-INFRASTRUCTURE SYSTEM (2015 - Ongoing). The National Integrated Cyber-Infrastructure (NICIS) was formalized in 2015 in South Africa, to provide overall cyber-infrastructure services and resources to rest of the South African researchers. It is part of the following theme(s): Open science and enhanced access to publications and research data, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The main goal is to support all national funded research initiatives in the country and provide infrastructure to allow for open science. The policy of the South African government is to enable access to all publicly funded data, and thus the role of NICIS is to provide such support. To this end, Data Intensive Research Initiative of South Africa (DIRISA) drives this initiative. It uses Information services and access to datasets as policy instruments.

title: South Africa
heading: THE NATIONAL EQUIPMENT PROGRAMME
content: South Africa's THE NATIONAL EQUIPMENT PROGRAMME (2015 - Ongoing). NEP is an Infrastructure Funding Instrument that support the acquisition, upgrade and development, of state-of-the-art research equipment. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The NEP, through a competitive peer review process, makes funds available to support the acquisition, upgrade or development of state-of-the-art research equipment. This involves major items of equipment that support multi-disciplinary and inter-disciplinary research and usually requires significant capital investment. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: South Africa
heading: MARINE AND ANTARCTIC RESEARCH STRATEGY
content: South Africa's MARINE AND ANTARCTIC RESEARCH STRATEGY (2016 - Ongoing). The Marine and Antarctic Research Strategy was constructed from the bottom up by consolidating separate research plans for the marine and Antarctic domains, respectively, drawn up by the relevant research communities, under the guidance of the National Research Foundation and with the involvement of researchers from the Department of Environment Affairs (DEA) It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, International co-operation, Support for public research, development and innovation. It has the following objective(s): identifying overlap and synergy between the two research plans, and prioritising research themes identified jointly between the DST and DEA. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Spain
heading: Grants for Training in Health Research Management (FGIN)
content:
Spain's Grants for Training in Health Research Management (FGIN) (2013 - Ongoing). Scholarships devoted to health research management It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): a) Development of a training plan in research management in health sciences and technologies to be carried out at the ISCIII.
b) The aim of these is to promote the training of specialists in this field, by learning aspects related to management, monitoring and ex-ante and ex-post evaluation of AES actions, as well as internationalization and innovation activities in the field of health sciences and technologies.
c) The beneficiaries will follow a common training program designed by the ISCIII and, additionally, each of them will develop a project focused on innovation or improvement of some aspect related to R & D & i management. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Spain
heading: Contracts for Health Research Management (GIS)
content:
Spain's Contracts for Health Research Management (GIS) (2014 - Ongoing). These contracts are aimed towards managers who carry out support activities for managing R&D&I activities in the accredited Health Research Institutes -IIS. The duration of this contract is 3 years. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): a) Improve the management capacity of the Health Research Institutes IIS.
b) Supporting initiatives for the management and valorization of innovation in these institutions.
c) Contribute to the internationalization of the IIS activity. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Germany
heading: FUNDING INSTRUMENTS FOR INSTITUTIONAL PARTNERSHIPS
content: Germany's FUNDING INSTRUMENTS FOR INSTITUTIONAL PARTNERSHIPS (1995 - Ongoing). The aim of the funding programme is to establish long-term research presence with top research facilities in target countries. The objective is to achieve an improved visibility of German scientific excellence in the partner countries and a joint contribution to boosting the STI systems both in Germany and the partner countries to their mutual benefit. It is part of the following theme(s): ERA-related strategies, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The target of this funding instrument is to support closer institutional collaboration between German and foreign research institutions by creating joint institutes and centers, joint labs, etc.. It uses nan as policy instruments.

title: Germany
heading: FUNDING PROGRAMMES IN THE FIELD OF INNOVATION AND APPLIED RESEARCH
content: Germany's FUNDING PROGRAMMES IN THE FIELD OF INNOVATION AND APPLIED RESEARCH (2016 - Ongoing). The calls are mainly aimed at companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as well as research institutions and universities (2+2) in Germany and in the target country that are active in the field of research. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, Internationalisation in public research, Targeted support to SMEs. It has the following objective(s): The object of funding are high-risk industrial research and pre-competitive development projects that are cross-technology and application oriented. These R&D projects must important for the companys positioning on the market. It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments.

title: European Union
heading: FET FLAGSHIP- HUMAN BRAIN PROJECT
content:
European Union's FET FLAGSHIP- HUMAN BRAIN PROJECT (2013 - Ongoing). The Human Brain Project (HPB) FET Flagship, as part of its multiple R&D activities, pushes the use of most advanced AI techniques for accelerating progress neurosciences and simultaneously develops more empowering robotics and AI approaches inspired by the latest understanding in the human brain, in particular regarding environment awareness and decision making (related budget part is indicated below). It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Thanks to knowledge management (including brain atlases), AI and brain modeling/simulation, a paradigm shift in the progress toward our understanding of how the human brain works and is affected by diseases. The goal is double:
(1) to allow the development of new brain health approaches, including public health and personalised diagnosis and treatments; (2) to emulate its computational capabilities in new electronic processors (aka neuromorphic) and new AI and cognitive robotics approaches with better environment awareness and decision making capabilities. An ICT-based Research Infrastructure for neurosciences - "EBRAINS" - open to researchers in Europe and beyond, with rich data collections and brain models covering multiple levels of the brain functioning structures. The constituting IT tools allow (a) curation, referencing, archiving and use of neuroscience data under the FAIR principle, (b) reproduceable and collaborative analysis and simulation workflows including with virtual robotics, (c) scaffolds for brain model development including for robots or other autonomous systems, etc. The tools are based on a cloudified approach around HPC centers and neuromorphic platforms, and with also distributed competence and laboratory facilities across Europe. Development of Ethics and RRI approaches to accompany the above two objectives, including in collaboration with other large brain research initiatives in the world, under the umbrella of the International Brain Initiative (IBI). It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Latvia
heading: SUPPORT FOR INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION PROJECTS IN RESEARCH AND INNOVATION
content: Latvia's SUPPORT FOR INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION PROJECTS IN RESEARCH AND INNOVATION (2017 - Ongoing). Promote Latvia’s participation in the EU research and technology development programmes (HORIZON 2020, Joint Programming initiatives, and activities under Article 185. and 187). It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, International mobility of human resources, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): Ensuring participation in the Joint Programming Initiatives strengthening the representation of national interests in Brussel activities with Latvian diaspora working in research and innovation participating in ERA-NET COFUND projects Implementating well-evaluated (above threshold) H2020 projects (ERA Chairs, MSCA, ERC) increasing the performance in H2020 It uses Project grants for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Belgium - Wallonia
heading: LIVING LABS
content: Belgium - Wallonia's LIVING LABS (2014 - Ongoing). A Living lab is a place to design innovative products and services by placing the user at the heart of the innovation process. It is part of the following theme(s): Cluster policies, Collaborative research and innovation, Research infrastructures, Stimulating demand for innovation and market creation. It has the following objective(s): In the spirit of open innovation, they include different types of public and private actors (companies, research laboratories, local authorities, potential users, ...) and aim at going further in the creation of innovative products and services testing them "live" and developing a strategic vision of their potential usage. A Living Lab is usually focused on a specific theme or area. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Mexico
heading: Programa de Laboratorios Nacionales
content: Mexico's Programa de Laboratorios Nacionales (2013 - Ongoing). Programa de apoyo a institutos públicos de investigación nacionales. Programa presupuestario. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Proveer apoyo económico complementario para consolidar laboratorios nacionales que sean producto de la asociación de dos o más instituciones de diferentes regiones del país, lo que permite expandir las capacidades científico‐tecnológicas de los diversos grupos de investigación. Las unidades que conforman a estos laboratorios están orientadas a la investigación científica, al desarrollo tecnológico, a la formación de recursos humanos y a la prestación de servicios, dentro de un marco de sustentabilidad y calidad. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: China
heading: KEY TECHNOLOGIES R&D PROGRAM
content: China's KEY TECHNOLOGIES R&D PROGRAM (1982 - Ongoing). The programme aims to provide technical support to industrial restructuring, the sustainable development of society, and the enhancement of living standards by achieving breakthroughs in key technologies, introducing technical innovation and applying high and new technologies. It is part of the following theme(s): Business innovation policy strategies, Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Boost sustainable development. Enhance the national S&T strength and innovation capacity. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: China
heading: NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY FOR DEEP LEARNING
content: China's NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY FOR DEEP LEARNING (2017 - Ongoing). The laboratory was established to accelerate research related to AI. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To support research and commercial applications of AI. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: NATIONAL SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL
content: United States's NATIONAL SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL (1993 - Ongoing). This Cabinet-level Council is the principal means within the Executive Branch to coordinate science and technology policy across the diverse entities that make up the Federal research and development enterprise. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Horizontal policy coordination. It has the following objective(s): A primary objective of the NSTC is establishing clear national goals for Federal science and technology investments in a broad array of areas spanning virtually all the mission areas of the Executive Branch. The Council prepares research and development strategies that are coordinated across Federal agencies aimed at accomplishing multiple national. It uses Horizontal STI coordination bodies as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: PARTNERSHIPS FOR INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION
content: United States's PARTNERSHIPS FOR INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION (2005 - Ongoing). Partnerships for International Research and Education (PIRE) is an NSF-wide program that supports international activities across all NSF-supported disciplines. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, International STI governance policy. It has the following objective(s): The primary goal of PIRE is to support high quality projects in which advances in research and education could not occur without international collaboration. PIRE seeks to catalyze a higher level of international engagement in the U.S. science and engineering community It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: PARTNERSHIPS FOR ENHANCED ENGAGEMENT IN RESEARCH
content: United States's PARTNERSHIPS FOR ENHANCED ENGAGEMENT IN RESEARCH (2011 - Ongoing). The Partnerships for Enhanced Engagement in Research (PEER) program is a competitive awards program, supported by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and implemented by the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NAS), that invites scientists in developing countries to apply for funds to support research and capacity-building activities on topics of importance to USAID and conducted in partnership with U.S. Government (USG)-supported and selected private sector partners. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Internationalisation in public research, Research and innovation for developing countries. It has the following objective(s): The PEER program is meant to leverage investments by other USG agencies and the private sector in scientific research and training in order to enhance the development priorities of USAID. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Italy
heading: EUROPEAN STRATEGY FORUM ON RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES
content: Italy's EUROPEAN STRATEGY FORUM ON RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES (2010 - Ongoing). Italy is pursuing a policy of adopting the European excellence criteria through its participation in the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI). It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Italy through its participation in the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures (ESFRI), aims to qualify its own research infrastructures by opening them to international access and by participating in the pan-European networks of Research Infrastructures and the preparatory phases of the new ESFRI infrastructures. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Switzerland
heading: Swiss Roadmap for Research Infrastructures
content: Switzerland's Swiss Roadmap for Research Infrastructures (2011 - Ongoing). The Swiss Roadmap for Research Infrastructures is a planning instrument for research infrastructures. The report is updated by SERI every four years in preparation for the ERI (Education, Research and Innovation) Dispatch. It gives an overview of future needs and likely developments in different areas of research. The 2019 Roadmap therefore serves as a basis for the 2021–2024 ERI Dispatch. It is part of the following theme(s): Public research strategies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The national roadmap process serves to prepare and prioritise, in terms of research policy, future, long-term investments in newly planned or ongoing national and international research infrastructures with Swiss participation. Set out future investments to be considered for the development of important research fields of national interest and for synergies between national and international research projects. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Switzerland
heading: SWISS INNOVATION PARK
content: Switzerland's SWISS INNOVATION PARK (2015 - Ongoing). The Swiss Innovation Park is a private-public partnership of national importance funded and operated by the Confederation and cantons, science community and the private sector, helping to make Switzerland attractive for high-value R&D collaboration between academia/science and industry. It is part of the following theme(s): Business innovation policy strategies, Collaborative research and innovation, Foreign direct investment, Research infrastructures, Transfer and linkages strategies. It has the following objective(s): Making Switzerland more attractive for private R&D investment. Tackling both transnational corporate structures and R&D headquarters as well as small and medium sized companies. Offering by the Confederation of space (construction sites) close to world-renown universities and technological institutes, offering by the Confederation of loan guarantees for research infrastructures (not buildings). The private foundation “Swiss Innovation Park” acts as the national point of contact for several sites of the Swiss Innovation Park and manages the loan guarantees. The foundation is fully privately financed, the role of the Confederation is subsidiary, i.e. the Confederation enabled the political process and parliaments decision. The Swiss Innovation Park is realized by the cantons, by the research institutions and universities and the private sector. The SIP forms an ecosystem that allows universities and innovative companies to collaborate and use their research results for the development of new marketable products and services Its purpose is to develop private research and development investment in Switzerland and so provide a valuable addition to the established funding instruments in Switzerland. This new approach seeks to make Switzerland attractive to international research and development players by providing developed parcels of land and floor space with expansion potential in the vicinity of existing higher education institutions and businesses. It uses Debt guarantees and risk sharing schemes, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: Kazakhstan
heading: BASIC FUNDING
content: Kazakhstan's BASIC FUNDING (2011 - Ongoing). Basic funding is distributed to public research institutions and public higher education institutions to conduct research on the fields determined by an authorized govermental body. In order to be eligible for basic funding, PRIs and HEIs should have performed state tasks or state orders over the past two years. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Covering the costs of scientific infrastructure and property, including buildings, equipment and materials, salaries of administrative and service personnel, as well as information support of scientific and technical activities of the public research institutions and higher education institutions. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Bulgaria
heading: ERA-NET COFUND ACTIONS
content: Bulgaria's ERA-NET COFUND ACTIONS (2014 - Ongoing). The National Science Fund has participated in nine ERA-NET Cofund actions It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): The actions support public-public partnerships in preparation, establishment of networking structures, design, implementation and coordination of joint activities. It uses Project grants for public research, Grants for business R&D and innovation, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Bulgaria
heading: ORDINANCE FOR CONDITIONS AND ORDER OF ASSESSMENT, PLANNING, ALLOCATION AND EXPENDITURE OF FUNDS FROM THE STATE BUDGET FOR FINANCING THE INHERENT OF STATE UNIVERSITIES SCIENTIFIC OR ARTISTIC ACTIVITY
content: Bulgaria's ORDINANCE FOR CONDITIONS AND ORDER OF ASSESSMENT, PLANNING, ALLOCATION AND EXPENDITURE OF FUNDS FROM THE STATE BUDGET FOR FINANCING THE INHERENT OF STATE UNIVERSITIES SCIENTIFIC OR ARTISTIC ACTIVITY (2014 - Ongoing). Planning of the funds for the inherent of State Universities scientific and artistic activity carried out within the terms of forming the state budget. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Determines the conditions and order of assessment, planning, allocation and expenditure of the funds, provided purposely by the state budget for the inherent of State Universities scientific or artistic activity, as well as related activities, regulated in the regulations of the respective State University. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Bulgaria
heading: ESFRI-ERIC PARTICIPATION
content:
Bulgaria's ESFRI-ERIC PARTICIPATION (2008 - Ongoing). Bulgarian research teams have access to several international and European Research Infrastructures, such as CERN, Dubna, ITER, and several ESFRI-ERICs as CLARIN, Euro-Argo, ESS, STA-Magic, EPOS, PRACE, Euro-Bioimaging. It is part of the following theme(s): Internationalisation in public research, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Accessing Research Infrastructures with modern equipment and good organization is fundamental for building a
critical mass of material, financial and human resources as well as technological knowledge. Shared usage of large infrastructures is essential to avoid overlapping and to concentrate resources at EU level. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Kazakhstan
heading: SHARED RESEARCH LABORATORIES
content: Kazakhstan's SHARED RESEARCH LABORATORIES (2011 - Ongoing). The laboratories are created in the form of a structural subdivision of a scientific organization or a higher educational institution, or in the form an independent legal entity and function. The laboratories provide access for research by domestic and foreign scientists, regardless of the departmental affiliation and ownership of the scientific organization or higher educational institution in which they work. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): to achieve an advanced level of research and development to ensure the effective use of material, technical and personnel potential of the laboratory. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: France
heading: AI FOR HUMANITY - NATIONAL STRATEGY IN ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
content: France's AI FOR HUMANITY - NATIONAL STRATEGY IN ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (2018 - Ongoing). The objective of this plan: to propel France among the champions of artificial intelligence, with the following priorities: research, openness of data and ethical or societal issues. It is part of the following theme(s): Public research strategies, Research infrastructures, STI plan or strategy. It has the following objective(s): talents: attract the best expertise in artificial intelligence data: fuel ai dissemination in the economy and society ethics: commit dialogue between performance and humanity It uses Strategies, agendas and plans, Regulatory oversight and ethical advice bodies, Science and technology regulation, Institutional funding for public research, Formal consultation of stakeholders or experts as policy instruments.

title: Germany
heading: FUNDING INITIATIVE INTERNATIONAL FUTURE LABS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
content:
Germany's FUNDING INITIATIVE INTERNATIONAL FUTURE LABS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (2019 - Ongoing). With this funding initiative, the BMBF supports the establishment and work of three international research teams in Germany (Berlin, Hannover and Munich), which conduct research on current AI research and development issues. Each future laboratory is funded with up to 5 million EUR over a period of 3 years. Funding began in May 2020. The projects focus on the development of AI technologies for earth observation, personalized medicine as well as for development of new medical drugs and the production of sustainable plastics and raw materials. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, International mobility of human resources. It has the following objective(s): The competition is aimed at
1 - bringing together researchers from around the world to work on current artificial intelligence research and development issues;
2 - fostering the transfer of knowledge and technology and
3- raising the international profile of Germany as a research and innovation hub. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Australia
heading: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL TRANSLATION CENTRE INITIATIVE
content: Australia's NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL TRANSLATION CENTRE INITIATIVE (2014 - Ongoing). The NHMRC Translation Centre Initiative comprises Advanced Health Research and Translation Centres (AHRTCs) and Centres for Innovation in Regional Health (CIRHs). The core aim of the NHMRC Translation Centre initiative is to encourage excellent health research and translation in Australia by bringing together researchers, healthcare providers, education and training to improve the health and well-being of patients and the populations they serve, including in regional/remote areas. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Recognise leading centres of collaboration in Australia that excel in the provision of research based health care and training for the populations they serve. Encourage excellent health research and translation in Australia by bringing together researchers, healthcare providers, education and training. Improve the health and well-being of healthcare patients, including vulnerable populations and those living in regional and remote areas. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Formal consultation of stakeholders or experts as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: INDUSTRY-UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE RESEARCH CENTRES
content: United States's INDUSTRY-UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE RESEARCH CENTRES (1973 - Ongoing). Programme allowing universities to establish research centres that develop long-term partnerships among industry, academia and government. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Doctoral and postdoctoral researchers. It has the following objective(s): Contributing to the nations research enterprise by developing long-term partnerships among industry, academe, and government. Leveraging NSF funds with industry to support graduate students performing industrially relevant pre-competitive research. Expanding the innovation capacity of the nations competitive workforce through partnerships between industries and universities. Encouraging the nation’s research enterprise to remain competitive through active engagement with academic and industrial leaders throughout the world. As appropriate, NSF encourages international collaborations that advance these goals within the global context. It uses Centres of excellence grants, Centres of excellence grants as policy instruments.

title: Czech Republic
heading: ROADMAP OF LARGE RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES OF THE CZECH REPUBLIC
content: Czech Republic's ROADMAP OF LARGE RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES OF THE CZECH REPUBLIC (2016 - Ongoing). The Roadmap of Large Infrastructures for Research, Experimental Development and Innovation for the years 2016-2022 (first edition in 2010, updated in 2011, 2015 and 2019) is a strategy document. The development of research infrastructures became one of the governmental priorities in the field of RDI policy in 2009, when the respective funding instrument had been embedded into the legislation of the Czech Republic. The most recent update of the National Roadmap was approved by the Government of the Czech Republic in November 2019. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): provide a strategic framework model for the large research infrastructures’ support in the current multi-annual financial framework 2016-2022 It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Germany
heading: UNDERSTANDING SOCIETY – SHAPING THE FUTURE: HUMANITIES AND SOCIAL SCIENCES
content: Germany's UNDERSTANDING SOCIETY – SHAPING THE FUTURE: HUMANITIES AND SOCIAL SCIENCES (2019 - Ongoing). With the Framework Programme for the humanities and social sciences, the Federal Ministry of Education and Research strengthens the humanities and social sciences in their efforts to contribute to the development of a sustainable society by, among other things, promoting research on societal challenges, experimental and development spaces for science and research infrastructures. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Strengthening the humanities and social sciences Promotion of research on societal challenges Promotion of applied research It uses Institutional funding for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Germany
heading: CITY OF THE FUTURE
content: Germany's CITY OF THE FUTURE (2016 - Ongoing). Initiative for sustainable and innovative city planning. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Mission-oriented innovation policies, Public research strategies, Research and innovation for society strategy. It has the following objective(s): The objective of the initiative is to support application-oriented, cross-departmental and trans-disciplinary research and innovation projects that contribute to the sustainable development of cities. It uses Project grants for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Germany
heading: REINHARD KOSELLECK PROJECTS
content: Germany's REINHARD KOSELLECK PROJECTS (2008 - Ongoing). This programme enables outstanding researchers with a proven academic track record to pursue innovative, higher-risk projects (funding duration: 5 years). It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): to enable innovative, high-risk projects It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Slovenia
heading: VEGA SUPER COMPUTER
content: Slovenia's VEGA SUPER COMPUTER (2019 - Ongoing). With the HPC VEGA project, Slovenia is setting up supercomputer centre at PETA scale level. Project has clear orientation towards research that includes fields of artificial intelligence, processing big data (smart cities, IoT...), medicine, new materials, mechanical engineering and all other advanced science areas. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To establish a national high-performance computing infrastructure. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Canada
heading: STEM CELL NETWORK
content: Canada's STEM CELL NETWORK (2016 - Ongoing). The Stem Cell Network (SCN) is a national not-for-profit corporation dedicated to enabling the translation of stem cell research into clinical applications, commercial products and public policy. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Ethics of emerging technologies, High-risk high-reward research, STI human resources strategies, Third-party funding. It has the following objective(s): To support world-class stem cell research and the translation of that research into applications that provide economic and social benefits for Canada. To create national and international partnerships that bring together key individuals and organizations in the stem cell field. To develop a pool of Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP) trained to undertake future stem cell research. To transform knowledge of the ethical, economic, legal and social challenges and opportunities related to stem cells into sound public policies and practices. To strengthen Canada’s international leadership and reputation in the stem cell field. It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Malta
heading: NATIONAL SPACE RESEARCH FUND
content: Malta's NATIONAL SPACE RESEARCH FUND (2017 - Ongoing). A funding programme that supports research and innovation projects within the downstream Earth observation space sector. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding, Internationalisation in public research, Support for public R&D and infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To build capacity within the Maltese downstream space sector, in particular that related to Earth observation. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Austria
heading: FORTE - DEFENCE RESEARCH PROGRAMME
content: Austria's FORTE - DEFENCE RESEARCH PROGRAMME (2018 - Ongoing). FORTE supports national defence research projects, targeting capability needs of the Austrian Armed Forces. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Support the competitiveness and R&D capabilities of the Austrian defence industry. Close capability gaps in the Austrian Armed Forces. Establish the Austrian Federal Ministry of Defence as a viable R&D partner. Empower the Austrian defence industry to compete sucessfully in EU research programmes It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Malta
heading: BILATERAL FUND WITH THE FRENCH SPACE AGENCY
content: Malta's BILATERAL FUND WITH THE FRENCH SPACE AGENCY (2019 - Ongoing). This funding programme supports space related projects between Maltese stakeholders and their counterparts within the French Space Agency (CNES) It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, International co-operation, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): To build capacity within the Maltese space sector through the transfer of knowledge between CNES experts and Maltese researchers It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Malta
heading: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY CO-OPERATION- SINO-MALTA FUND
content: Malta's SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY CO-OPERATION- SINO-MALTA FUND (2019 - Ongoing). To intensify scientific collaboration between Malta and the People's Republic of China. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): To help strengthen R&I activities. To facilitate technology transfer. To carry out comprehensive, steady and long-term co-operation through support of researchers mobility and the networking of industries, universities and research institutions to generate mutual beneficial research. It uses Project grants for public research, Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Malta
heading: THE JOINT PROGRAMMING INITIATIVES HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE SEAS AND OCEANS
content: Malta's THE JOINT PROGRAMMING INITIATIVES HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE SEAS AND OCEANS (2014 - Ongoing). JPIOceans is an intergovernmental platform, open to all EU member states and associated countries who invest in marine and maritime technologies It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, International co-operation, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research, Support for public research, development and innovation. It has the following objective(s): Facilitating long-term collaboration between EU Member states, associated countries and international partners on the subject of marine and maritime research. It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms, Grants for business R&D and innovation, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Malta
heading: ERANET CO-FUND ON THE BLUE BIOECONOMY
content: Malta's ERANET CO-FUND ON THE BLUE BIOECONOMY (2018 - Ongoing). This ERANET Co-Fund is the result of a collaboration between JPIOceans and the former ERANETs COFASP and ERA MBT and consists of 27 partners from 16 countries. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, International STI governance policy, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): To establish a co-coordinating R&D Funding scheme that will strengthen Europes position in the maritime Bioeconomy It uses Project grants for public research, Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Malta
heading: THE PARTNERSHIP FOR RESEARCH AND INNOVATION IN THE MEDITERRANEAN AREA
content: Malta's THE PARTNERSHIP FOR RESEARCH AND INNOVATION IN THE MEDITERRANEAN AREA (2018 - Ongoing). PRIMA is a Joint Programme to facilitate Euro-Mediterranean co-operation in the field of water management, sustainable agriculture and agro-food systems. It is part of the following theme(s): Cluster policies, Collaborative research and innovation, Commercialisation of public research results, Cross-disciplinary research, Internationalisation in public research, Research and innovation for developing countries. It has the following objective(s): Build research and innovation capacities Develop knowledge and common innovative solutions for agro-food systems, to make them sustainable For integrated water provision and management in the Mediterranean area Facilitate the provision and management of more climate resilient, efficient, cost effective and environmentally and socially sustainable innovations To contribute to solving water scarcity, food security, nutrition, health, well-being and migration problems upstream It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms, Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Canada
heading: EXPERIMENTATION WORKS
content: Canada's EXPERIMENTATION WORKS (2018 - Ongoing). Experimentation Works (EW) is a Government-of-Canada-wide initiative to build public servants’ capacity in experimentation skills and practice through a learning-by-doing model that provides access to design expertise. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Support department-led experiments by providing access to experimental design expertise Build capacity and practical understanding related to the value and process of experimentation Provide access to related learning modules, progress updates and results for broad impact. Maintain an active experimentation community of practice It uses Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: Lithuania
heading: COMPETITIVE PRIORITY RESEARCH PROGRAMMES
content: Lithuania's COMPETITIVE PRIORITY RESEARCH PROGRAMMES (2019 - Ongoing). The competitive Priority Research Programme mobilizes the available intellectual potential of a country to address a strategically important issue for the State and society and makes an influence on the development of the country and science. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Research and innovation for society strategy. It has the following objective(s): To create new scientific knowledge and intellectual products, to develop research competence. It uses Project grants for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Lithuania
heading: TOWARDS FUTURE TECHNOLOGIES - NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAMME
content: Lithuania's TOWARDS FUTURE TECHNOLOGIES - NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAMME (2016 - Ongoing). The programme is designed to create the preconditions for the development of future technologies and to enhance the potential of Lithuanian higher education and research institutions and prepare them for participation in the research and technologies programmes implemented by the European Space Agency. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): to create a favourable international context and the conditions for research to build up a basis for developing future technologies, promoting innovations and enhancing Lithuanias competitiveness and security It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Lithuania
heading: NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAMME HEALTHY AGEING
content: Lithuania's NATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAMME HEALTHY AGEING (2015 - Ongoing). To obtain the new scientific knowledge required to extend the duration of a healthy and quality life in Lithuania. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Ethics of emerging technologies. It has the following objective(s): To find solutions regarding issues in the healthy ageing biomedicine and social medicine of Lithuanian society through the development of science and technologies, as well as the results of fundamental and applied research. It uses Project grants for public research, Formal consultation of stakeholders or experts as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Canada
heading: INTERNATIONAL ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATORIES PROGRAM
content: Canada's INTERNATIONAL ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATORIES PROGRAM (1978 - Ongoing). A transfer payment program providing contributions to international observatories to support the pre-construction, construction, management and operations of offshore ground-based observatories and their related facilities. It is part of the following theme(s): Internationalisation in public research, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To ensure Canada plays a prominent role in international scientific endeavours by providing Canadian astronomers with access to leading-edge facilities and technology and Canadian students and post-doctoral research with access to advance their training. To ensure Canada plays a prominent role in international scientific endeavours by providing Canadian industry with opportunities to participate in advanced scientific projects and opportunities to benefit from contracts and technology development. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: Canada
heading: NRC Challenge Programs
content: Canada's NRC Challenge Programs (2019 - Ongoing). To catalyze transformative, high-risk, high-reward research with the potential for game-changing scientific discoveries and technological breakthroughs, the National Research Council of Canada’s (NRC) scientists work with innovators form post-secondary institutions and businesses on multi-party research and development programs. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Mission-oriented innovation policies, Stimulus for STI systems. It has the following objective(s): To bring together the best minds from academia, industry and government to focus on disruptive technologies that will benefit Canadians. The Challenge Programs are expected to strengthen collaborations across industry, academia, and government to support research excellence. To develop new and potentially disruptive technologies with collaborators from industry, academia, and government To deliver collaborative solutions to address public policy challenges It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Canada
heading: NRC IDEATION FUNDING
content: Canada's NRC IDEATION FUNDING (2018 - Ongoing). Acting as a discovery and demonstration phase for a continually-evolving suite of R&D deliverables at the National Research Council of Canada (NRC), the Ideation Fund supports self-directed exploratory research projects with external collaborators. Two types of projects are supported – one-year projects with single NRC + collaborator engagement; three-year projects with NRC team + collaborator team engagement. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Strengthen collaborations across industry, academia, and government to support research excellence Inform the development of new and potentially disruptive technologies with collaborators. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Korea
heading: The Alchemist Project
content: Korea's The Alchemist Project (2019 - Ongoing). This project aims at promoting disruptive and break-through technologies for future generations with the help of R&D challenges It is part of the following theme(s): Green energy transitions, High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): To promote challenging R&D programs to tackle with industrial sticking points It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Mexico
heading: National System of Researchers
content: Mexico's National System of Researchers (1984 - Ongoing). The National System of Researchers (Sistema Nacional de Investigadores - SNI) was created to provide a recognition to workers engaged in the production of scientific and technological knowledge. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Research careers, STI human resources strategies. It has the following objective(s): Promote and raise, through evaluation, the quality of scientific and technological research, and the innovation taking place in Mexico. Contributes to the training and consolidation of researchers with advanced scientific and technological knowledge, considered as an essential element to increase culture, productivity, competitiveness and social well being. Ensure the quality of results of the R&D activities performed by researchers. Evaluate members with high standards, including the production of high quality scientific and technological knowledge. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Creation or reform of governance structure or public body as policy instruments.

title: Australia
heading: ANTARCTIC SCIENCE COLLABORATION INITIATIVE
content: Australia's ANTARCTIC SCIENCE COLLABORATION INITIATIVE (2019 - Ongoing). ASCI will deliver against the Australian Government’s commitment to provide strategic, long-term investment in Antarctic science and support our science and research priorities, particularly those relating to climate science. In particular, it will support leading Australian research agencies to work together on Antarctic research to understand the role of the Antarctic region in the global climate system and the implications for marine ecosystems. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, International co-operation, Support for public research, development and innovation. It has the following objective(s): to support research that aims to understand the role of the Antarctic region in the global climate system and the implications on marine ecosystems to enable the Australian Antarctic Program Partnership to undertake collaborative science, research and innovation activities under the Australian Antarctic Science Strategic Plan and Australian Antarctic Strategy and 20 Year Action Plan to secure Antarctic science jobs in Hobart It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Russian Federation
heading: RUSSIAN FOUNDATION FOR ADVANCED RESEARCH PROJECTS
content: Russian Federation's RUSSIAN FOUNDATION FOR ADVANCED RESEARCH PROJECTS (2012 - Ongoing). The Foundation supports research in military-technical, technological and socio-economic spheres, development of innovative technologies and production of high-tech military, special and dual-use products. It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): Support for R&D in the field of defense and state security It uses Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments.

title: Austria
heading: ERWIN SCHROEDINGER CENTER FOR QUANTUM SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
content: Austria's ERWIN SCHROEDINGER CENTER FOR QUANTUM SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY (2016 - Ongoing). ESQ is an Austria-wide Postdoc Programme to support the integration of incoming experienced researchers in Austrian research institutions and a Discovery Programme that shall allow exploring highly innovative research beyond any traditional thinking. It is part of the following theme(s): Doctoral and postdoctoral researchers, High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): Strengthen quantum physics research in Austria Support Austria as innovation location It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Austria
heading: INNOVATION FUND: RESEARCH, SCIENCE AND SOCIETY
content: Austria's INNOVATION FUND: RESEARCH, SCIENCE AND SOCIETY (2015 - Ongoing). The Innovation Fund supports extraordinarily innovative projects. It distributes funding for innovative approaches, ideas and methods. The Fund supports projects that cannot access funding from other agencies due to disciplinary or topical restrictions or because the projects take high risks given their uncertain outcome. It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): Support research projects and initiatives that open doors to new paradigms and create new methodologies. Support for high-risk approaches, ideas and methods in research It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Russian Federation
heading: WORLD-CLASS RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL CENTRES
content: Russian Federation's WORLD-CLASS RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL CENTRES (2019 - Ongoing). Establishment of no less than 15 world class research and educational centres is one of the tasks set in the Presidents Decree of 7 May 2018 No 204, and one of the new initiatives within the national project "Science" aimed at supporting science-industry collaboration. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Third-party funding. It has the following objective(s): Stimulate science-industry collaboration in Russian regions, develop new technologies within the S&T priorities of the Russian Federation, produce high-tech and innovative goods. It uses Centres of excellence grants as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: United States
heading: NSF SUPPORT TO AI R&D
content: United States's NSF SUPPORT TO AI R&D (2018 - Ongoing). NSF invests nearly $500 million annually in fundamental research, workforce development, and advanced, scalable computing resources that collectively advance artificial intelligence (AI). It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, STEM skills. It has the following objective(s): To enable research advances: NSF’s investments in AI span foundational as well as translational (application-driven) research. A significant investment in AI foundations is through the Division of Information and Intelligent Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Sciences and Engineering (CISE), which provides $120 million annually across the breadth of AI research and development (R&D), including machine learning, reasoning and problem solving, knowledge representation, planning and scheduling, natural language processing, decision making, human-machine interaction, AI and ethics, and more. Advances in AI are also core to many of NSF’s 10 Big Ideas, notably Harnessing the Data Revolution and Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier. Workforce: NSF is funding research and development that is building the necessary foundations for implementing rigorous and engaging computer science education at all levels: pre-K-12, colleges/universities, and continuing education programs.§ Computer Science for All: Researcher Practitioner Partnerships (CSforAll: RPP)—aims to provide all U.S. students the opportunity to participate in computer science (CS) and computational thinking education in their schools at the preK-12 levels.§ Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Computing in Undergraduate Education (IUSE: CUE)—re-envisions the role of computing in undergraduate education, where CS student populations are larger and more diverse, and seeking to pursue careers in both CS and non-CS fields that require computational competencies to be used collaboratively across different contexts. § Future of Work at the Human Technology Frontier—aims to understand and develop the human-technology partnership, design new technologies to augment human performance, understand the risks/benefits and impacts of new technologies and AI on workers and work, and foster lifelong and pervasive learning.NSF is also prioritizing AI opportunities within existing Foundation-wide fellowship and educational programs, including Graduate Research Fellowships and NSF Research Traineeships. Data and Advanced Computing: A Driver of Modern AIAdvances in AI rely upon the availability of high-quality datasets as well as advanced, scalable computing resources. NSF supports high-performance computing (HPC) resources that advance the full range of computational- and data-intensive science and engineering research, including AI. In 2018, NSF awarded $60 million to the University of Texas at Austins Texas Advanced Computing Center to deploy Frontera, the largest and most powerful supercomputer the agency has ever supported.In addition, NSF has launched a new program, Enabling Access to Cloud Computing Resources for CISE Research and Education (CloudAccess), to enable the research community to access cloud computing platforms, which provide robust, agile, reliable, and scalable infrastructure. NSF Leadership in AI Across the U.S. GovernmentNSF leadership plays an important role in helping drive and coordinate AI R&D efforts across the Federal Government through the National Science and Technology Council (NSTC).NSTC Select Committee on AI. The NSF Director co-chairs this committee, which advises The White House on interagency AI R&D priorities and establishes structures to improve government planning and coordination of AI R&D including with academia and industry.NSTC Machine Learning and AI Subcommittee. The NSF Assistant Director for CISE co-chairs this subcommittee, which serves as the implementation arm for the Select Committee on AI, and also co-chairs the NSTC Networking and Information Technology Research and Development (NITRD) Subcommittee.NSTC/NITRD Artificial Intelligence R&D Interagency Working Group. The NSF/CISE Division Director for Information and Intelligent Systems (IIS) co-chairs this group, which is updating the 2016 National AI R&D Strategic Plan and will issue a Progress Report to accompany the updated Plan. The NSF Program on Fairness in Artificial Intelligence in Collaboration with Amazon aims at building trustworthy AI systems that are readily accepted and deployed to tackle grand challenges facing society. Specific topics of interest include transparency, explainability, accountability, bias, mitigation strategies, validation, and inclusivity. AI and Society, supported jointly with the Partnership on AI, aims at understanding the social challenges arising from AI technology and enable scientific contributions to overcome them. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Institutional funding for public research, Project grants for public research, Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments.

title: Russian Federation
heading: AGROBIOTECHNOPARKS
content:
Russian Federation's AGROBIOTECHNOPARKS (2019 - Ongoing). Agrobiotechnoparks will be created with the support of regional executive bodies and will provide a transfer of acquired knowledge to production practice, acting as an incubator for further replication of the result. They shall erncompass centers of competence providing technology transfer and the link between basic, exploratory and applied science and industry; prototyping centers; logistics centers;
laboratories for quality control and analysis in the field of crop production and animal husbandry; marketing service; outreach events (exhibitions, experimental and demonstration sites. It is part of the following theme(s): Cluster policies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Create added value from enabling complex interactions between existing and newly created objects of scientific and innovative infrastructure Launching educational programs for graduate and PhD students, including online forms for the implementation of educational programs It uses Technology extension and business advisory services, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: Portugal
heading: "SCIENCE" Meetings
content: Portugal's "SCIENCE" Meetings (2019 - Ongoing). Annual meetings of Portuguese Research and Innovation communities. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Multi-stakeholder engagement, Science, technology and innovation culture. It has the following objective(s): Promoting a broad debate on the main topics and challenges of the scientific agenda beyond the world of research. to stimulate interactions between researchers, the business sector and the general public. It uses Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities as policy instruments.

title: Poland
heading: [NCN] IdeaLab – GROUND-BREAKING, INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROJECTS
content: Poland's [NCN] IdeaLab – GROUND-BREAKING, INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROJECTS (2019 - Ongoing). IdeaLab is an innovative, interdisciplinary call for researchers from Poland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein, targeted at research projects that address important social challenges covered by the topic ‘Managing threats’. The IdeaLab call concerns challenges arising from complex processes of our times, such as globalisation, technological change, issues of environment and climate change, demographic change, major waves of migration, geopolitical instability and many others, which bring with them uncertainties (implying threats and, in some cases, opportunities) that European societies have to face. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): To develop research-based knowledge relevant for social challenges. To enhance research cooperation between Poland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein To support the development of ground-breaking, interdisciplinary and innovative research project ideas It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: United States
heading: ARPA-E FUNDING
content: United States's ARPA-E FUNDING (2009 - Ongoing). ARPA-E (Advanced Research Projects Agency – Energy) funds technology-focused, applied research and development address the full range of energy-related technologies It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): overcoming specific technical barriers around a specific energy area, creating real-world solutions to important problems in energy creation, distribution, and use funding solicitations aimed at supporting America’s small business innovators. to identify high-potential projects that address the full range of energy-related technologies, through periodic Funding Opportunity Announcements (FOAs) It uses Information services and access to datasets, Project grants for public research, Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: SOCIAL INNOVATION FUND
content: United States's SOCIAL INNOVATION FUND (2009 - Ongoing). The SIF is committed to investing in innovative solutions that displace ineffective programs. For the SIF, “social innovation” means “new ways to solve old problems that are faster, cost-effective, data-driven and lead to better results for the public good.” Although the practice of social innovation is commonly understood to be the invention and testing of new ideas, the SIF seeks to support innovations that have advanced beyond the beginning stages, are showing signs of effectiveness, and have the potential for greater scale. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Multi-stakeholder engagement, Research and innovation for society strategy. It has the following objective(s): support innovations that have advanced beyond the beginning stages, are showing signs of effectiveness, and have the potential for greater scale. combine public and private resources to grow promising community-based solutions that have evidence of results in any of three priority areas: economic opportunity, healthy futures, and youth development. provide grants to experienced grantmaking “intermediaries” that are well-positioned within communities to identify the most promising programs and guide them towards greater impact and stronger evidence of success. It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation, Policy intelligence (e.g. evaluations, benchmarking and forecasts), Information services and access to datasets as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: DARPA FUNDING ANNOUNCEMENTS
content: United States's DARPA FUNDING ANNOUNCEMENTS (2014 - Ongoing). Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) publicly announces research programs for which it seeks research contractors. It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): To invest in high-risk, high-payoff research. To tackle some of the most difficult challenges for protecting national security. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: UNIVERSITY CENTER ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM
content: United States's UNIVERSITY CENTER ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM (1980 - Ongoing). The University Center (UC) program supported by the Economic Development Administration EDA is about long-term partnerships in economic development. Typical actions provided by the UCs include targeted commercialization of research, workforce development, and business counseling services. Other UCs may focus their efforts on helping local organizations with conducting preliminary feasibility studies, analyzing data, and convening customized seminars and workshops on topics such as regional strategic planning and capital budgeting. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Commercialisation of public research results, Non-competitive research funding, Research and innovation for developing countries, STEM skills. It has the following objective(s): To marshal the resources located within colleges and universities to support regional economic development strategies in regions of chronic and acute economic distress. To devote the majority of their funding to respond to technical assistance requests originating from organizations located in the economically distressed portions of their service regions. rTo ecognize and respond to the needs of small- and medium-sized manufacturers and processors for technology transfer and commercialization assistance To focus efforts on assisting units of local governments and nonprofit organizations in planning and implementing regional economic development strategies and projects. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Technology extension and business advisory services, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: DEFENSE EDUCATION AND CIVILIAN UNIVERSITY RESEARCH
content: United States's DEFENSE EDUCATION AND CIVILIAN UNIVERSITY RESEARCH (2019 - Ongoing). Defense Education and Civilian University Research supports basic research projects that improve capacities in defense-related basic social science to inform Department of Defense (DoD) policy makers and decision leaders. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): develop collaborative basic research partnerships between Defense Professional Military Education (PME) Institutions and Civilian Research Universities Increase DoD social science expertise by investing in experts who teach our future military and national security leaders at Professional Military Education (PME) institutions. Build deeper understanding of the social, cultural, and political factors and dynamics that shape U.S. security interests around the world. Improve knowledge brought into the classroom and increase PME institutions’ ability to inform and help contribute to civilian social science dialogue Encourage and facilitate better connections across PME institutions for those experts with complementary intellectual and research interests. Enhance civilian scientist awareness of critical social science challenges confronting the DoD, encourage civilian academics to collaborate and engage with PME instructors and their students at PME institutions It uses Institutional funding for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: MINERVA
content: United States's MINERVA (2008 - Ongoing). Launched by the Secretary of Defense in 2008, the Minerva Research Initiative is a Department of Defense-sponsored, university-based social science research initiative that focuses on areas of strategic importance to the U.S. national security policy. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): to promote research in specific areas of social science and to promote a candid and constructive relationship between the Department of Defense and the social science academic community. to bring together universities and other research institutions around the world and support multidisciplinary and cross-institutional projects addressing specific interest areas determined by the Department of Defense. To support social science research aimed at improving our basic understanding of security, broadly defined It uses Project grants for public research, Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: DOE ENERGY INNOVATION HUBS
content: United States's DOE ENERGY INNOVATION HUBS (2012 - Ongoing). The hubs combine the R&D firepower of five Department of Energy national laboratories, five universities, and four private firms in an effort aimed at achieving revolutionary advances in battery performance It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): to overcome the scientific barriers to the development of a complete energy system that has potential for implementation into a transformative energy technology, by supporting multiple research teams - each working in separate but collaborative research areas. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: ENERGY FRONTIER RESEARCH CENTERS
content: United States's ENERGY FRONTIER RESEARCH CENTERS (2009 - Ongoing). nan It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Non-competitive research funding, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): bringing together creative, multi-disciplinary scientific teams to tackle the toughest scientific challenges preventing advances in energy technologies. take full advantage of powerful new tools for characterizing, understanding, modeling, and manipulating matter from atomic to macroscopic length scales. train the next-generation scientific workforce by attracting talented students and postdoctoral researchers interested in energy science. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Networking and collaborative platforms, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: PHOTOVOLTAICS COMPETITIVE AWARDS
content: United States's PHOTOVOLTAICS COMPETITIVE AWARDS (2005 - Ongoing). In support of the goals of the photovoltaics subprogram, the Energy Department issues competitive solicitations to fund targeted research projects through funding opportunity announcements (FOAs). Awards are made to universities, national laboratories, and industry. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation. It has the following objective(s): foster cooperative research, development, demonstration, and deployment projects by private companies, universities, state and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and national laboratories to drive down the cost of solar electricity to $0.03 per kilowatt-hour (not including incentives). It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation, Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: INTERNATIONAL PARTNERSHIP FOR HYDROGEN AND FUEL CELLS IN THE ECONOMY
content: United States's INTERNATIONAL PARTNERSHIP FOR HYDROGEN AND FUEL CELLS IN THE ECONOMY (2003 - Ongoing). The United States is a founding member of the International Partnership for Hydrogen and Fuel Cells in the Economy (IPHE), which was created in 2003. The IPHEs 17 partners organize, evaluate, and coordinate multinational research, development, and deployment programs that will advance the introduction of fuel cells and hydrogen infrastructure at a global scale. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, International STI governance policy, Stimulating demand for innovation and market creation. It has the following objective(s): foster international cooperation on hydrogen and fuel cell R&D, common codes and standards, and information sharing on infrastructure development establish an effective operational structure to facilitate international collaboration and networking both among researchers and at the highest levels of government leverage resources by endorsing 30 international collaborative projects, co-labeled over 13 workshops and conferences, and sponsored a series of workshops on topics ranging from hydrogen storage to infrastructure issues It uses Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities, Standards and certification for technology development and adoption, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: CONCENTRATING SOLAR POWER COMPETITIVE AWARDS
content: United States's CONCENTRATING SOLAR POWER COMPETITIVE AWARDS (2007 - Ongoing). The Concentrating Solar Power Competitive Awards by the Solar Energy Technologies Office (SETO) at the Department of Energy are geared towards transformative concepts with the potential to break through existing cost and performance barriers. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation. It has the following objective(s): To support the development of novel concentrating solar power (CSP) research and development projects that will reduce the levelized cost of energy to $0.05 per kilowatt hour or less, for baseload systems with 12 hours or more of thermal energy storage, without subsidies by 2030. To engineer new concepts in the collector, receiver, thermal storage, heat transfer fluids and power cycle subsystems, including technologies that will lower operations and management costs Develop solutions that are commercially relevant for electricity generation applications. It uses Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: SUNSHOT NATIONAL LABORATORY MULTIYEAR PARTNERSHIP
content: United States's SUNSHOT NATIONAL LABORATORY MULTIYEAR PARTNERSHIP (2016 - Ongoing). The SunShot National Laboratory Multiyear Partnership (SuNLaMP) funding program allows the Energy Department’s national laboratory system to continue to address the most critical barriers that remain to achieving a total installed cost of solar energy systems to $.06 per kilowatt-hour by 2020. SuNLaMP projects address all five of SunShot’s subprograms in fiscal years 2016 through 2018. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): enables our country’s national laboratories to address the most impactful barriers to the advancement of photovoltaic (PV) technologies. Research at these labs has advanced key PV technologies and has enabled the solar industry to grow. target high-impact problems, make a significant difference in research areas, focus on broad problems with new approaches, and have a significant return on investment. meet agreed-upon objectives, deliver on milestones, yield valuable results, and remain relevant to the current research and development needs of the technology and the solar marketplace. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: The 21st CENTURY CURES ACT
content: United States's The 21st CENTURY CURES ACT (2016 - Ongoing). This piece of legislation provides NIH with critical tools and resources to advance biomedical research across the spectrum, from foundational basic research studies to advanced clinical trials of promising new therapies. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Mission-oriented innovation policies. It has the following objective(s): To provide multiyear funding to four highly innovative scientific initiatives: The All of Us Research Program, formerly known as the PMI Cohort Program; The Brain Research through Advancing Innovative Neurotechnologies (BRAIN) Initiative seeks to better understand how the brain encodes, stores, and retrieves information, which will transform the ability to diagnose and treat neurological/mental disorders; The Cancer Moonshot; and The Regenerative Medicine Innovation Project will support clinical research in coordination with the FDA using adult stem cells to further the field of regenerative medicine. To provide NIH with the flexibility and resources needed to accomplish its mission to improve the health of Americans. To implement measures to alleviate administrative burdens that can prolong the start of clinical trials and improve privacy protections for research volunteers. To implement measures to enhance data sharing among NIH-supported researchers and allow researchers to more easily attend scientific conferences where in-person collaboration can often lead to scientific breakthroughs. To implement measures to encourage inclusion of diverse populations represented in clinical research and open up new NIH funding opportunities for young investigators. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans, Institutional funding for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms, Information services and access to datasets as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION COOPERATIVE INSTITUTES
content: United States's NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION COOPERATIVE INSTITUTES (2004 - Ongoing). NOAA Cooperative Institutes are academic and non-profit research institutions that demonstrate the highest level of performance and conduct research that supports NOAAs Mission Goals and Strategic Plan. Many of the Cooperative Institutes are collocated with NOAA research laboratories, creating a strong, long-term collaboration between scientists in the laboratories and in the university. The laboratories and their field stations are located across the country and around the world. Cooperative Institutes not collocated with a NOAA laboratory often serve diverse research communities and research programs throughout NOAA.
