It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): conduct an integrated program of research, technology development, and services to improve the understanding of Earths atmosphere, oceans and inland waters, and to describe and predict changes occurring to them. It uses Information services and access to datasets, Horizontal STI coordination bodies, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM
content: United States's NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM (1966 - Ongoing). Sea Grant is a Federal-University partnership program that brings science together with communities for solutions that work. The Sea Grant network consists of a federal/university partnership between the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and 33 university-based programs in every coastal and Great Lakes state, Puerto Rico, and Guam. It is part of the following theme(s): Capacity development in science, technology, engineering and mathematical disciplines, Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Multi-stakeholder engagement. It has the following objective(s): drawing on the expertise of more than 3,000 scientists, engineers, public outreach experts, educators and students to help citizens better understand, conserve and utilize Americas coastal resources. identifying and prioritizing needs on a regional level as a cornerstone of sound ocean, coastal and Great Lakes ecosystem management. Continuing to solidify regional partnerships in each of the eight NOAA regions, bringing together academic institutions, federal, state and local government agencies, and non‐governmental organizations to address regional issues. It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: THE WEATHER RESEARCH AND FORECASTING INNOVATION ACT
content: United States's THE WEATHER RESEARCH AND FORECASTING INNOVATION ACT (2017 - Ongoing). The Weather Research and Forecasting Innovation Act of 2017 (the Weather Act) bolsters the Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Researchs (OAR) commitment to advancing weather research and reinvigorating the weather portfolio. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): ensuring alignment of office practices with the strategic goals outlined in the Weather Act. collaborating with various subject matter experts across NOAA to develop Congressional reports and deliverables required by the Weather Act, and briefing NOAA leadership on OAR-related activities and reports. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Formal consultation of stakeholders or experts as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: CLIMATE PROGRAM OFFICE RESEARCH GRANTS
content: United States's CLIMATE PROGRAM OFFICE RESEARCH GRANTS (2018 - Ongoing). Funding projects that are designed to improve our ability to describe our changing environment. Some anticipated outcomes include improved early warning of drought, enhanced prediction of coastal high water levels, a better understanding of emissions from wildfires, and region-driven resilience building with stakeholders and communities. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Support for public research, development and innovation. It has the following objective(s): To improve our ability to describe our changing environment. To advance understanding, modeling, and prediction of the Earth system. To foster effective decision making. It uses Project grants for public research, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: U.S. GLOBAL CHANGE RESEARCH PROGRAM
content: United States's U.S. GLOBAL CHANGE RESEARCH PROGRAM (2012 - Ongoing). The U.S. Global Change Research Program (USGCRP) is a Federal program mandated by Congress. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): To coordinate Federal research and investments in understanding the forces shaping the global environment, both human and natural, and their impacts on society. To facilitates collaboration and cooperation across its 13 Federal member agencies. It uses Horizontal STI coordination bodies, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: ELECTRICITY INDUSTRY TECHNOLOGY AND PRACTICES INNOVATION CHALLENGE
content: United States's ELECTRICITY INDUSTRY TECHNOLOGY AND PRACTICES INNOVATION CHALLENGE (2019 - Ongoing). The Electricity Industry Technology and Practices Innovation Challenge (EITPIC) taps into American ingenuity to make the nation’s electric grid stronger and more resilient. Through the challenge, the Office of Electricity seeks ideas from industry, academia, and other innovators for technologies or solutions that can address existing or emerging vulnerabilities and threats to the electric sector or mitigate interdependencies between the electricity sector and other sectors. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation. It has the following objective(s): Seeks ideas from industry, academia, and other innovators for technologies or solutions that can address existing or emerging vulnerabilities and threats to the electric sector or mitigate interdependencies between the electricity sector and other sectors. It uses Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: MATERIALS GENOME INITIATIVE
content: United States's MATERIALS GENOME INITIATIVE (2011 - Ongoing). The Materials Genome Initiative is a multi-agency initiative designed to create a new era of policies, resources, and infrastructures for materials research. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Ethics of emerging technologies, Public research strategies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To support U.S. institutions in the effort to discover, manufacture, and deploy advanced materials twice as fast, at a fraction of the cost. To combine computational tools, experimental tools, and digital data to develop and advance high-tech, high-performing materials. To improve the prediction and optimization of materials properties. To develop new techniques, standards, and tools for the broader research community. It uses Horizontal STI coordination bodies, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: LARGE-SCALE FOSSIL FUEL PILOT PROJECTS
content: United States's LARGE-SCALE FOSSIL FUEL PILOT PROJECTS (2017 - Ongoing). The U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE) Office of Fossil Energy (FE) has selected six projects to receive approximately $14.7 million in federal funding for Phase II of funding opportunity announcement (FOA), Fossil Fuel Large-Scale Pilots. Two final projects were selected to proceed with construction and operation of large-scale pilot facilities. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, Stimulating demand for innovation and market creation. It has the following objective(s): support a range of potentially transformational coal technologies aimed at enabling step-change improvements in coal-powered systems. support future design and construction of the next generation of coal fired power plants that are flexible, resilient, economical, and emit near zero emissions, including carbon dioxide. support efforts to secure team commitments; update the preliminary cost estimate and schedule for design, construction and operation; secure construction/operation cost-share funding; and complete an environmental information volume. complete a front-end engineering design study and complete the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) process. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: PREVENTION RESEARCH CENTERS
content: United States's PREVENTION RESEARCH CENTERS (2014 - Ongoing). The Prevention Research Centers (PRCs) are a network of 26 academic research centers in the United States It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): study how people and their communities can avoid or counter the risks for chronic illnesses, conducting projects with under-served populations that have high rates of disease and disability. conduct projects with community partners who are engaged throughout the research effort Conduct special Interest Projects focusing on topics of interest or gaps in scientific evidence Form thematic networks across centers to focus on specific health topics. It uses Project grants for public research, Information services and access to datasets, Centres of excellence grants as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: THEMATIC RESEARCH NETWORKS
content: United States's THEMATIC RESEARCH NETWORKS (2002 - Ongoing). There are currently five thematic research networks. Past networks have addressed oral health, tobacco use prevention, school health, women’s health, healthy aging, and cardiovascular health. Each of them funds several Prevention Research Centers (PRC) to work together on a specific health issue. One PRC in the network is the coordinating center and manages the initiative. The networks assign a technical advisor from the funding agency to work with the network members. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): nan It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: AIR, CLIMATE AND ENERGY CENTERS
content: United States's AIR, CLIMATE AND ENERGY CENTERS (1999 - Ongoing). The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is providing $30 million in funding for three university-based Air, Climate and Energy (ACE) Centers. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): conduct research on regional differences in air pollution and the effects of global climate change, technology, and societal choices on local air quality and health. develop effective pollution control strategies to protect air quality at the state and local levels. using integrated and multidisciplinary scientific approaches to find new solutions to protect air quality in the midst of a changing climate and changing energy production choices. It uses Information services and access to datasets, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: CENTERS OF EXCELLENCE IN REGULATORY SCIENCE AND INNOVATION
content: United States's CENTERS OF EXCELLENCE IN REGULATORY SCIENCE AND INNOVATION (2013 - Ongoing). The Food and Drug Administrations (FDA) Centers of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSIs) are collaborations between FDA and academic institutions to advance regulatory science through innovative research, training, and scientific exchanges. Evolving areas of science are promising new approaches to improving our health while demanding new ways to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the products FDA regulates. It is part of the following theme(s): Ethics of emerging technologies, Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To develop the tools, standards, and approaches required to assess the safety, efficacy, quality, and performance of innovative products. To harness these newly developed tools, standards, and approaches in collaboration with academia, industry, and other governmental agencies. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities, Technology extension and business advisory services, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: IARPA BETTER EXTRACTION FROM TEXT TOWARDS ENHANCED RETRIEVAL
content: United States's IARPA BETTER EXTRACTION FROM TEXT TOWARDS ENHANCED RETRIEVAL (2018 - Ongoing). IARPA invests in high-risk, high-payoff research programs to tackle some of the most difficult challenges of the agencies and disciplines in the Intelligence Community. Through Broad Agency Announcements (BAAs), IARPA publicly announces research programs for which it seeks research contractors. BAAs are preceded by consultations with the industry/research organizations and universities. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): to develop enhanced methods for personalized, multilingual semantic extraction and retrieval from text. provide users with a system that quickly and accurately extracts complex semantic information, targeted for a specific user, from text. uses this extracted information to discover and triage relevant documents from a large corpus. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: NASA SPACE GRANT PROGRAM: National Space Grant College and Fellowship Project
content: United States's NASA SPACE GRANT PROGRAM: National Space Grant College and Fellowship Project (1989 - Ongoing). Space Grant is a national network of colleges and universities. These institutions are working to expand opportunities for Americans to understand and participate in NASAs aeronautics and space projects by supporting and enhancing science and engineering education, research and public outreach efforts. The Space Grant national network includes over 850 affiliates from universities, colleges, industry, museums, science centers, and state and local agencies. It is part of the following theme(s): Cluster policies, Competitive research funding, Human resources and STEM. It has the following objective(s): Encourage cooperative programs among universities; aerospace industry; and Federal, state and local governments. Establish and maintain a national network of universities. Encourage interdisciplinary education, research and public service programs related to aerospace. Recruit and train U.S. citizens, especially women, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities. Promote a strong science, mathematics and technology education base from elementary through secondary levels. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Project grants for public research, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities as policy instruments.

title: Latvia
heading: BALTIC RESEARCH PROGRAMME
content: Latvia's BALTIC RESEARCH PROGRAMME (2018 - Ongoing). The Baltic Research Cooperation Program creates the conditions for better cooperation between Norwegian, Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian researchers and helps to find new partners. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): The Baltic Research programme shall strengthen multilateral relations with the aim of stimulating strong and sustainable collaboration, complementarity, capacity and competence-building and future collaborative research projects on EU and regional level. Indirectly, the program will have a broader impact and also increase the impact of Baltic researchers on pan-European cooperation, including participation in the European Union Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, Horizon Europe. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: United States
heading: DEVELOPMENT INNOVATION VENTURES
content: United States's DEVELOPMENT INNOVATION VENTURES (2010 - Ongoing). Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) is the U.S. Agency for International Developments (USAID) open innovation program that tests and scales creative solutions to any global development challenge. It is part of the following theme(s): Access to finance for innovation, Competitive research funding, Research and innovation for developing countries. It has the following objective(s): By investing in breakthrough innovations driven by rigorous evidence, USAID impacts millions of lives at a fraction of the usual cost. provide flexible, tiered grant funding to test new ideas, take strategic risks, build evidence of what works, and advance the best solutions. We look for solutions that demonstrate rigorous evidence of impact, cost-effectiveness, and a viable pathway to scale and sustainability. It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation, Project grants for public research, Equity financing, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities, Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: COOPERATIVE RESEARCH UNITS
content: United States's COOPERATIVE RESEARCH UNITS (1935 - Ongoing). Today, there are 40 Cooperative Research Units in 38 states. Each unit is a partnership among the U.S. Geological Survey, a State natural resource agency, a host university, and the Wildlife Management Institute. It is part of the following theme(s): Doctoral and postdoctoral researchers, Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): to enhance graduate education in fisheries and wildlife sciences to facilitate research between natural resource agencies and universities on topics of mutual concern. It uses Information services and access to datasets, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities, Networking and collaborative platforms, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH ACT PROGRAM
content: United States's WATER RESOURCES RESEARCH ACT PROGRAM (1984 - Ongoing). The Water Resources Research Act Program is a Federal-State partnership. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To plan, facilitate and conduct research that helps resolve State and regional water problems. To promote technology transfer, dissemination and application of research. To train scientists through participation in research To award competitive grants under the Water Resources Research Act. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships, Information services and access to datasets, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: Malta
heading: MCAST RESEARCH FRAMEWORK
content:
Malta's MCAST RESEARCH FRAMEWORK (2019 - Ongoing). The Applied Research and Innovation Centre (ARIC) strategy is anchored on the premise of making existing structures more flexible, and fostering their ability to innovate, react and respond. The strategy's three main underlying pillars are
1. A focus on key, select research thrusts leading to smart specializations.
2. Creating and working within one or more Knowledge Centre / R&I Ecosystem, Centres for Smart Specialization, and peer learning through international networks such as ASEF, Eurashe and UAS4Europe.
3. Developing and propagating new research, innovation and pedagogical & andragogic methodologies and technologies. It is part of the following theme(s): Entrepreneurship capabilities and culture, High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): All MCAST Senior Lecturers, Associate Professors and Full Professors are expected to carry out academic research related to their area of specialization as directed by MCAST. Each institute at MCAST has a Senior Research Officer (SROs) in order to drive and support the adoption of research initiatives by institute academic staff and to facilitate inter and intra institute research initiatives. Additionally, the SROs work with academics in drafting research proposals pre-award and to be familiar with different funding options available for research in the MCAST vocational areas. SROs also help to support the lecturers in putting together research funding bids. To establish and promote adequate processes and procedures to incentivize the lecturing staff to embark on new projects at national and international level. To establish research partnerships within and outside the College It uses Institutional funding for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Malta
heading: PARTICIPATION IN BBMRI-ERIC (EUROPEAN RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE FOR BIOBANKING)
content: Malta's PARTICIPATION IN BBMRI-ERIC (EUROPEAN RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE FOR BIOBANKING) (2013 - Ongoing). The Malta National Node is the smallest within the BBMRI-ERIC. The Malta Biobank was developed jointly between the University of Malta and the Malta Department of Health. It holds a population bank and a clinical bank with specific collections. The Population Bank is a discovery tool for biobanking / population led research. The PI is co-founder of Euro-Bio-Bank, the first European network of Rare Disease Bio-Banking. It is part of the following theme(s): Cluster policies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The Malta National Node takes active part in BBMRI activities with special interest in quality measures and rare disease matters. It is also interested in the further development of Rare Disease Bio-Banking and a broader Euro-Mediterranean engagement. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Information services and access to datasets as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Colombia
heading: LINKING KNOWLEDGE
content: Colombia's LINKING KNOWLEDGE (2019 - Ongoing). Public call for programs and projects that generate knowledge along prioritized research lines through collaborations between research groups. The call also wants to support young researchers who are working in the obtaining or improvement of products, services, processes and their application. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Cross-disciplinary research, STI plan or strategy. It has the following objective(s): Foster programs and projects that generate knowledge along prioritized lines of research To support and associate young researchers to supported projects. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Ireland
heading: FUTURE INNOVATOR PRIZE
content:
Ireland's FUTURE INNOVATOR PRIZE (2018 - Ongoing). The Future Innovator Prize is a challenge-based prize programme which aims to support the formation of diverse interdisciplinary teams to develop novel, potentially disruptive, technologies to address significant societal challenges. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, Ethics of emerging technologies, Mission-oriented innovation policies, Research and innovation for developing countries, Research and innovation for society strategy. It has the following objective(s): To support development of novel, potentially disruptive, technologies to address significant
national and global challenges. To support the formation of high-performance interdisciplinary teams based on integration of
diverse STEM disciplines and complementary skillsets. To promote convergence of knowledge, practice and methods from different disciplines and
sectors. To promote engagement between researchers and stakeholders/beneficiaries of research. To accelerate societal impact from publicly funded research It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Belgium - Brussels Capital
heading: BRAINS FOR BRUSSELS
content: Belgium - Brussels Capital's BRAINS FOR BRUSSELS (2015 - Ongoing). Through this programme, a researcher who has the intention of moving to Brussels benefits from a financial intervention for the development of an innovation scientific research project. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Doctoral and postdoctoral researchers, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): Stimulate the mobility of researchers It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: United States
heading: BASIC BEHAVIORAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE OPPORTUNITY NETWORK
content: United States's BASIC BEHAVIORAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE OPPORTUNITY NETWORK (2009 - Ongoing). NIH initiated the Basic Behavioral and Social Science Opportunity Network (OppNet) in November 2009 to expand the NIH portfolio in basic scientific inquiry that explains the mechanisms and processes that influence individual and group health-related behaviors. By September 2018, OppNet provided $80,750,002 to 137 extramural research projects including out-year funding. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To pursue opportunities for strengthening basic behavioral and social science research (b-BSSR) at the NIH while innovating beyond existing investments. Foster advances basic behavioral and social science research through activities and initiatives that build a body of knowledge about the nature of behavior and social systems. Prioritize activities and initiatives that focus on basic mechanisms of behavior and social processes; that are relevant to the missions and public health challenges of multiple NIH Institutes, Centers and Offices (ICOs); and that build upon existing NIH investments without replicating them. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: BIOMEDICAL INFORMATION SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INITIATIVE
content: United States's BIOMEDICAL INFORMATION SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INITIATIVE (2000 - Ongoing). BISTI is a consortium of representatives from each of the NIH institutes and centers. BISTI was established in May 2000 to serve as the focus of biomedical computing issues at the NIH. Regular monthly meetings are conducted to discuss program status, future needs and directions, and topics of interest to the bioinformatics community. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): make optimal use of computer science and technology to address problems in biology and medicine by fostering new basic understandings, collaborations, and transdisciplinary initiatives between the computational and biomedical sciences. coordinate research grants, training opportunities, and scientific symposia associated with biomedical computing. It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms, Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: BLUEPRINT FOR NEUROSCIENCE RESEARCH
content: United States's BLUEPRINT FOR NEUROSCIENCE RESEARCH (2004 - Ongoing). A collaborative framework that includes the NIH Office of the Director and 14 NIH Institutes and Centers that support research on the nervous system. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To accelerate transformative discoveries in brain function in health, aging and disease. identify cross-cutting areas of research and confronts challenges too large for any single Institute or Center, by pooling resources and expertise In addition to supporting cross-cutting neuroscience activities like research training, workforce diversity, informatics and therapeutic development, Blueprint also funds research initiatives. It uses Information services and access to datasets, Project grants for public research, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Public awareness campaigns and other outreach activities as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: REHABILITATION R&D CENTERS AND RESEARCH ENHANCEMENT PROGRAMS
content: United States's REHABILITATION R&D CENTERS AND RESEARCH ENHANCEMENT PROGRAMS (2017 - Ongoing). Centers receive more funding that research enhancement programs It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): nan It uses Information services and access to datasets, Centres of excellence grants as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING TO THE CLINICAL CENTER AT THE NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
content: United States's INSTITUTIONAL FUNDING TO THE CLINICAL CENTER AT THE NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH (1953 - Ongoing). The Clinical Center at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) is the world’s largest hospital entirely devoted to clinical research. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): rapidly translate scientific observations and laboratory discoveries into new approaches for diagnosing, treating, and preventing disease. encourage the application of new findings in patients, often with the participation of investigators from outside institutions. excels in the type of basic research needed to advance biomedical knowledge, providing the very foundation for health research worldwide, as well as the type of clinical research that culminates in cures and therapies. serve the dual role of providing humane and healing patient care and an unparalleled environment for clinical researchers to advance biomedical science. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: NIH COMMON FUND
content: United States's NIH COMMON FUND (2006 - Ongoing). The Common Fund program complement NIHs other funding schemes. It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research, Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To address emerging scientific opportunities and pressing challenges in biomedical research that no single NIH Institute or Center (IC) can address on its own, but are of high priority for the NIH as a whole To function as a “venture capital” space where high-risk, innovative endeavors with the potential for extraordinary impact can be supported. to change paradigms, develop innovative tools and technologies, and/or provide fundamental foundations for research that can be used by the broad biomedical research community. It uses Institutional funding for public research, Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Colombia
heading: ACTIVITIES OF THE NATIONAL FUND FOR THE FINANCING OF STI FRANCISCO JOSÉ DE CALDAS
content: Colombia's ACTIVITIES OF THE NATIONAL FUND FOR THE FINANCING OF STI FRANCISCO JOSÉ DE CALDAS (2009 - Ongoing). The National Fund for the financing of Science, Technology and Innovation Francisco José de Caldas is a financial mechanism that allows COLCIENCIAS to include public, private, international and donation resources to finance Science, Technology and Innovation Development. The Fund is managed by a Trust company. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To finance Science, Technology and Innovation programs, projects, institutions and activities. To invest in Risk Capital Funds or other financing instruments, for supporting Science, Technology and Innovation programs, project and activities. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships, Horizontal STI coordination bodies, Institutional funding for public research, Centres of excellence grants, Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United States
heading: CounterACT PROGRAM
content: United States's CounterACT PROGRAM (2006 - Ongoing). The NIH is taking a leadership role in pursuing the development of new and improved medical countermeasures designed to prevent and treat the acute and long-term conditions caused by potential and existing chemical threat agents. Many of these same chemicals not only pose as a terrorist threat agent, they may also be released from transportation and storage facilities during industrial accidents or natural disasters. The overarching goal of the CounterACT program is to integrate cutting-edge research with the latest technological advances in science and medicine for a more rapid and effective response during these chemical emergencies. This NIH-led program includes a comprehensive network of Research Centers of Excellence, individual cooperative research projects, small business innovation research grants, contracts, and interagency agreements with the Department of Defense. It is part of the following theme(s): Business innovation policy strategies, Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, Public research strategies, Targeted support to young innovative enterprises. It has the following objective(s): development of new and improved medical countermeasures designed to prevent and treat the acute and long-term conditions caused by potential and existing chemical threat agents. To support basic and translational research aimed at the identification of better therapeutic medical countermeasures against chemical threat agents, and facilitates their movement through the drug development and regulatory processes in collaboration with other federal departments, agencies, and initiatives, such as the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (HHS BARDA) and the FDA Medical Countermeasures Initiative (MCMi). To improve the nations ability to diagnose, prevent, and treat injuries resulting from chemical attacks or accidents. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans, Grants for business R&D and innovation, Procurement programmes for R&D and innovation, Centres of excellence grants, Project grants for public research, Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation
heading: RESEARCH FUNDING FOR UNIVERSITY COLLEGES
content: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation's RESEARCH FUNDING FOR UNIVERSITY COLLEGES (2019 - Ongoing). The Research Funding for University Colleges is endowed with one million euros (annually indexed). This annual call is open to all disciplines. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Embedding sex- and gender-specific analysis in research. It has the following objective(s): Encourage interdisciplinary and inter-institutional research. Attract new research talents Promote the emergence and/or the development of research themes in University Colleges. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Estonia
heading: PROOF-OF-CONCEPT GRANT
content: Estonia's PROOF-OF-CONCEPT GRANT (2019 - Ongoing). A proof-of-concept (PoC) grant is a competency-based research funding instrument for experimental development in order to test and/or create conditions for the commercialization of research outcomes. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): enhancing technology transfer, the application of research outcomes in enterprises and in society. strengthening the societal and economic impact of research. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: New Zealand
heading: JAMES COOK RESEARCH FELLOWSHIPS
content: New Zealand's JAMES COOK RESEARCH FELLOWSHIPS (1995 - Ongoing). Fellowship awards to researchers who have achieved national and international recognition in their area of scientific research, allowing them to concentrate on their chosen research for two years without the additional burden of administrative and teaching duties. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To support researchers with knowledge, skills and ideas and to recognise research professionals of excellence. It is expected that a major piece of research will be undertaken that will benefit New Zealand and advance research in the particular science. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Türkiye
heading: SUPPORT PROGRAMME FOR R&D PROJECTS BY MINISTRY OF TRANSPORT AND INFRASTRUCTURE
content: Türkiye's SUPPORT PROGRAMME FOR R&D PROJECTS BY MINISTRY OF TRANSPORT AND INFRASTRUCTURE (2015 - Ongoing). R&D projects on Electronic Communications, Aviation, Space and Information Technologies are supported, in line with the duties and authorities given by Article 489 of the Presidential Decree No. 1. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Financial support to business R&D and innovation. It has the following objective(s): To promote and disseminate the production of electronic communications, aviation, space and information technologies with national resources. It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: PARTICIPATION IN M-ERA.NET 3
content: Hungary's PARTICIPATION IN M-ERA.NET 3 (2012 - Ongoing). M-ERA.NET is an EU funded network contributing to the restructuring of the European Research Area (ERA) by operating as a single innovative and flexible network of funding organisations. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): to support and increase the coordination of European research programmes and related funding schemes aiming at materials science and engineering. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: PARTICIPATION IN EUROPEAN JOINT PROGRAMME COFUND and ERA-NET COFUND PROGRAMMES
content: Hungary's PARTICIPATION IN EUROPEAN JOINT PROGRAMME COFUND and ERA-NET COFUND PROGRAMMES (2019 - Ongoing). The aim of the call financed from the National Research, Development and Innovation Fund is to provide the national contribution to Hungarian organisations successfully participating in the joint international ERA-NET COFUND and European Joint Programme COFUND (EJP COFUND) co-funded by the EU under its H2020 framework programme for research and innovation, in collaboration with the NRDI Office. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): The aim of the call financed from the National Research, Development and Innovation Fund is to provide the national contribution to Hungarian organisations successfully participating in the joint international ERA-NET COFUND and European Joint Programme COFUND (EJP COFUND) co-funded by the EU under its H2020 framework programme for research and innovation, in collaboration with the NRDI Office. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation
heading: LIFEWATCH WALLONIA-BRUSSELS
content: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation's LIFEWATCH WALLONIA-BRUSSELS (2012 - Ongoing). LifeWatch is a research program focusing on biodiversity and ecosystems It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Develop and operate a system for continuous mapping of biotopes and their spatial structure, capitalizing on a recognized Walloon expertise in the field of space applications. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: CALL FOR PROPOSALS - UNIVERSITY INNOVATION ECOSYSTEM
content: Hungary's CALL FOR PROPOSALS - UNIVERSITY INNOVATION ECOSYSTEM (2019 - Ongoing). The call of the National Research, Development and Innovation Office aims to facilitate the development and effective operation of a results-oriented innovation ecosystem at universities. The commercialisation of the R&D achievements of higher education institutions and an entrepreneurial approach developed in teachers, researchers and students are enabled by the management of technology transfer and innovation at institutional level. The programme is funded in two phases, in year 2021. beneficiaries are able to submit proposals in order to countinue the projects of the first phase. It is part of the following theme(s): Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, Entrepreneurship capabilities and culture. It has the following objective(s): Promote an active, mutually beneficial, business-focused relationship between universities and the business sector. Formulate the intellectual and infrastructural competencies of institutions as transparent services. Create a Single Point of Contact for businesses to reach a hub of connected higher education institutions. Facilitate results-oriented technology transfer and innovation management at the institutions. Develop an entrepreneurial approach in teachers, researchers and students. Commercialise institutional RDI results through synergies with the business sector. It uses Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Brazil
heading: BRICS SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION WORK PLAN
content: Brazil's BRICS SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION WORK PLAN (2019 - Ongoing). This Work Plan is organized in four main tracks of cooperation: (i) Research Collaboration, (ii) Research Infrastructure, (iii) Innovation Collaboration and (iv) Sustainability (long-term cooperation). It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, International STI governance policy, Research and innovation for developing countries, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The BRICS STI research collaboration is comprised of two main initiatives: the STI thematic working groups and the joint calls for research projects. In the thematic working groups, officials and researchers define lines of action; develop joint projects; exchange knowledge and experience in their areas of study; and decide the scope of the joint calls. The nine working groups in this category are: (i) Prevention and Monitoring of Natural disasters; (ii) New and renewable energy, and energy efficiency (with a sub-group on Solid State Lightning – SSL); (iii) Material Sciences and Nanotechnology; (iv) Information and Communication Technologies and High Performance Computing; (v) Astronomy; (vi) Biotechnology and Biomedicine, including human health and neuroscience; (vii) Ocean and polar science and technology; (viii) Geospatial technologies and its applications; (ix) Photonics. The BRICS Research Infrastructure (RI) collaboration is developed through the BRICS GRAIN Platform, which provides information and the list of available research opportunities for scientists. Furthermore, its key objectives include: i. Single entry point for potential Research Infrastructure Users and Partners: RI objects info, access/partnership policy, contacts; ii. Integrated source of BRICS RI people contacts, events as well as working proceedings regarding integrating, policy developing, communication initiatives, RI projects; iii. Up to date info for BRICS STI Senior Officials regarding BRICS RI WG progress. The activities for the 2019 - 2022 period of the BRICS Innovation Collaboration shall emphasize the proposal on STI-led innovation cooperation among BRICS countries announced at the 4th BRICS STI Ministerial Meeting in India (2016), and the implementation of the BRICS Action Plan on Innovation Cooperation 2017-2020, adopted by the 9th BRICS Summit (China, 2017). BRICS Governments should seek ways to make it sustainable long-term cooperation. That means they must create opportunities for scientific communities and enterprises strengthening their interactions and achieving joint concrete results, regardless of the direct involvement of the governments officials. It also means they should foster initiatives whose results can be felt during a long period of time. It uses Project grants for public research, Networking and collaborative platforms as policy instruments.

title: New Zealand
heading: ANTARCTIC SCIENCE PLATFORM
content: New Zealand's ANTARCTIC SCIENCE PLATFORM (2018 - Ongoing). The Antarctic Science Platform will provide stable funding for underpinning, longer-term Antarctic science research critical to maximising scientific and strategic benefits for New Zealand. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Improve scientific understanding of pressing issues such as climate change and ecosystem resilience. Safeguard the strategic benefits of New Zealands scientific activity in Antarctica. Optimise the value and impact of Antarctic science and Antarctic-related expenditure. Enable research focus and collaboration at a level not previously experienced in New Zealand. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: SUPPORTING THE USE OF INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES
content: Hungary's SUPPORTING THE USE OF INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES (2019 - Ongoing). Scheme to reimburse costs arising from the use of international research infrastructures by outgoing Hungarian researchers, PhD or MSc students; the travel and living costs of outgoing Hungarian researchers, PhD, or MSc students in the destination country; dissemination of research results achieved in the project; participation in international conferences. It is part of the following theme(s): Internationalisation in public research, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To support Hungarian researchers to use research and measurement services offered by international research infrastructures (RIs), particularly those in which Hungary holds full-fledged membership. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE COMMITTEE
content: Hungary's NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE COMMITTEE (2014 - Ongoing). The National Research Infrastructure Committee assists the National Research, Development and Innovation Office in the fulfillment of its public functions aimed at the sustainable development of the domestic RDI infrastructure. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures, Strategic policy intelligence. It has the following objective(s): The Committee is responsible for registering domestic research infrastructures and assessing development needs planning cooperation with foreign research infrastructures continuously monitoring effectiveness in the relevant fields of science and research. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans, Policy intelligence (e.g. evaluations, benchmarking and forecasts) as policy instruments.

title: Hungary
heading: NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE ROADMAP
content: Hungary's NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE ROADMAP (2018 - Ongoing). The National Research Infrastructure Roadmap presents the current situation of domestic research infrastructures, their connection to major international research infrastructures, the upgrading process and financial background of research infrastructures. It also highlights the need to monitor research infrastructures and identifies the criteria of monitoring and of setting development directions. It is part of the following theme(s): International STI governance policy, Public research strategies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): to identify the major research infrastructures (RIs) in Hungary, provide an insight into their operation, present the nature and diversity of domestic capacities and their connection to the international RI landscape draw the attention of the national and international research community to Hungarian research capacities and opportunities, provide background information for setting further development directions, and outline connection points to European infrastructures and cooperation relationships. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Portugal
heading: CÔA VALLEY INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAM
content: Portugal's CÔA VALLEY INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH PROGRAM (2019 - Ongoing). This initiative is intended to develop new knowledge in various thematic areas on the Côa Valley as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It supports scientific, cultural and artistic multidisciplinarity and contributes to a new international research agenda for the Côa Valley. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): Attracting research groups of international excellence to work in close cooperation with Portuguese research teams in the areas of Observation and knowledge of the earth; Climate and climate change; Origin of life and socio-cultural interaction dynamics over time; Biodiversity and biological resources, natural and cultural heritage and sustainable regional development. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Russian Federation
heading: GOVERNMENT AWARD FOR YOUNG RESEARCHERS
content: Russian Federation's GOVERNMENT AWARD FOR YOUNG RESEARCHERS (2004 - Ongoing). Seven Government Awards for Young Researchers (1 million rubles each) are given annually to applicants whose age should not exceed 33 years (besides those who are supervisors to a team of young scientists) It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Research careers. It has the following objective(s): Stimulating creative activity of young scientists It uses Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: New Zealand
heading: CORE FUNDING TO CROWN RESEARCH INSTITUTES
content: New Zealand's CORE FUNDING TO CROWN RESEARCH INSTITUTES (1992 - Ongoing). Crown-owned companies that carry out scientific research for the benefit of New Zealand, through addressing pressing issues, achieving economic growth by improving sectors’ productivity and improving the sustainable use of natural resources. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Commercialisation of public research results, Non-competitive research funding, Third-party funding. It has the following objective(s): Carry out research for the benefit of New Zealand Promote the application of the results of research and technological developments It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments.

title: New Zealand
heading: DATA SCIENCE RESEARCH PROGRAMMES
content: New Zealand's DATA SCIENCE RESEARCH PROGRAMMES (2019 - Ongoing). To harness the benefits of data science, New Zealand needs to be at the forefront of emerging data science technologies. This new investment of NZ$49 million over seven years will significantly lift New Zealand’s capability, provide fresh and ambitious thinking to support international and national collaborations in cutting edge data science research. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Deliver excellence: Produce excellent, cutting edge, dynamic and paradigm-shifting data science research. Grow capability: Grow the scale, depth, excellence and impact of New Zealand’s data science research community. The programmes will have strong leadership and multidisciplinary teams. They will attract top international researchers and support emerging researchers. Deliver additionality: Provide fresh and ambitious thinking, new people, new collaborations, new and expanded research, and new impacts that would not have happened without this investment. Leverage collaboration: Foster and grow international and national collaborations among data science researchers, and between data science researchers and end users. Collaborations should support research excellence and grow data science capabilities. Give effect to the Vision Mātauranga policy. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Slovak Republic
heading: EUROPEAN STRATEGY FORUM ON RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES
content: Slovak Republic's EUROPEAN STRATEGY FORUM ON RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES (2002 - Ongoing). ESFRI, the European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures, is a strategic instrument to develop the scientific integration of Europe and to strengthen its international outreach. The competitive and open access to high quality Research Infrastructures supports and benchmarks the quality of the activities of European scientists, and attracts the best researchers from around the world. ESFRI operates at the forefront of European and global science policy and contributes to its development translating political objectives into concrete advice for RI in Europe. It is part of the following theme(s): International STI governance policy, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): to support a coherent and strategy-led approach to policy-making on research infrastructures in Europe. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Korea
heading: The Project-based System for Funding Government R&D Program
content: Korea's The Project-based System for Funding Government R&D Program (1996 - Ongoing). Along with institutional funding for government research institutes (GRIs), a project-based system (PBS) was introduced to promote competitive funding and problem-solving research. Currently, the ratios of PBS in GRIs are between 30~60%. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To promote competitive funding to government research institutes To promote problem-solving research in GRIs It uses Science and technology regulation, Creation or reform of governance structure or public body as policy instruments.

title: Korea
heading: The Convergence Research Programme of the National Research Council of Science and Technology (NST)
content: Korea's The Convergence Research Programme of the National Research Council of Science and Technology (NST) (2014 - Ongoing). The Convergence research programme at the national research council of science and technology (NST) is composed of five categories: Convergence research center, creative allied project, civilian-military convergence research projects, advanced convergence research projects and convergence cluster projects. Each project is interconnected with the others. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): To promote systematic convergence research work in Government-funded Research Institutes (GRIs), aiming to solve national social issues as well as technical issues in the industry and to develop source technologies and leading technologies. To promote convergence research work in GRIs after the integration of the NST (July, 2014) and to remove silos among GRIs and produce large-scale research accomplishments. It uses Project grants for public research, Labour mobility regulation and incentives as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Estonia
heading: ROADMAP FOR NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES
content: Estonia's ROADMAP FOR NATIONAL RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURES (2019 - Ongoing). The Research Infrastructure Roadmap is a long-term (10-20 years) planning instrument which will be updated regularly (at an interval of 3 years). In 2018, the previous Roadmap was updated and the updated version was approved by Government Order No 43 from 14th of February 2019 as Supplement to the Implementation Plan for the Estonian Research, Development and Innovation Strategy 2014-2020 “Knowledge-based Estonia”. It is part of the following theme(s): Public research strategies, Research and innovation for society strategy, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The Estonian Roadmap for Research Infrastructures is a strategic initiative for planning and developing research infrastructures. The 2019 Roadmap lists 14 planned and 3 implemented research infrastructures of national importance. It includes also list of 14 Estonian participations in international research infrastructure organisations. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Belgium - Brussels Capital
heading: Ordinance on innovation clusters
content: Belgium - Brussels Capital's Ordinance on innovation clusters (2019 - Ongoing). This decree sets the legal framework for the Brussels Region to offer public funding dedicated to the creation of innovation clusters It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): the objective is to ensure that R&I infrastructures can apply for public funding within the legal framework of state aid regulation It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Regulatory oversight and ethical advice bodies as policy instruments.

title: United Kingdom
heading: SPACE WEATHER SERVICE
content: United Kingdom's SPACE WEATHER SERVICE (2013 - Ongoing). Provide space weather forecasts and warnings It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Support to central government to prepare for and mitigate for the impacts of a severe space weather event Warnings of enhanced activity to minimise business disruption Maintain awareness of the current space weather situation Improve sector resilience through increased sector awareness and clear identification of their needs. Tailored information to meet the generic needs of key sectors. Support space weather research and pull through models into operations. As the UK operational space weather provider, participate in international forums to improve governance and co-ordination of activities. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Canada
heading: FEDERAL SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE INITIATIVE
content: Canada's FEDERAL SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE INITIATIVE (2018 - Ongoing). The Federal Science and Technology Infrastructure Initiative (FSTII) is an ambitious whole-of-government 25-year transformative strategy, starting in 2018-19, to renew federal science and technology laboratories. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The goal is to achieve a world-class federal science and technology system to foster innovation and collaboration among the federal science community that signals a new and forward looking approach to science planning and collaboration. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: Türkiye
heading: CoHE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH PROJECTS
content: Türkiye's CoHE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH PROJECTS (2016 - Ongoing). The Council of Higher Education has numerous supporting incentives in terms of exchange programs for international mobilization, various fellowships for bachelors, Phd, post Phds careers for young researchers, research incentives for abroad studies at both institutional and researchers' level. It is part of the following theme(s): Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To provide support for scientific research projects of public universities To provide fellowships and research supports for bachelors, Phd, post Phds careers It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Thailand
heading: NSTDA SUPERCOMPUTER CENTER
content: Thailand's NSTDA SUPERCOMPUTER CENTER (2018 - Ongoing). NSTDA Supercomputer Center performs frontier research in computational science, data analytics and artificial intelligence (AI) as well as provides high performance computing service to researchers in Thailand to perform computational science research on challenges of national interest. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To provide HPC computing service for Thailand's R&D. To perform frontier computational science R&D. To promote development of HPC workforce. To develop HPC roadmap for Thailand. To establish partnership and visibility. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: Thailand
heading: NATIONAL OMICS CENTER
content: Thailand's NATIONAL OMICS CENTER (2018 - Ongoing). National Omics Center is a central facility fully equipped with cutting-edge genomic, proteomics, transcriptomic and metabolomics tools that enable biologists to generate and process omics data to support a better understanding of biological systems and eventually the development of successful innovations. It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To serve as a national infrastructure in genomic research. To advance Thailand's capability in genome technology. To provide solutions to researchers (government/private sectors). To utilize genomic research to create an impact on economy, society and the environment. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: Chile
heading: NATIONAL PRIZE OF SCIENCE
content: Chile's NATIONAL PRIZE OF SCIENCE (1992 - Ongoing). The National Prizes for Exact Sciences, for Natural Sciences and for Applied and Technological Sciences shall be awarded to scientists whose work in the respective field of knowledge merits such distinction. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To recognize excellent contributions of Chileans to the development of the state of knowledge in the Exact Sciences, Natural Sciences and Applied and Technological Sciences as well as the arts. It uses Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards, Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards, Science and innovation challenges, prizes and awards as policy instruments.

title: Belgium - Wallonia
heading: BELCOO (formerly BEL-SME)
content: Belgium - Wallonia's BELCOO (formerly BEL-SME) (2015 - Ongoing). Strengthen, through public funding, the scientific potential of regional Belgian SMEs through R&D collaboration in diverse and niche sectors. It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research, Financial support to business R&D and innovation, Horizontal policy coordination, Targeted support to SMEs. It has the following objective(s): Promote cooperation between SMEs from different Belgian regions. It uses Grants for business R&D and innovation as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation
heading: FORESIGHT COMMISSION
content: Belgium - Wallonia-Brussels Federation's FORESIGHT COMMISSION (2011 - Ongoing). Scientific commission that evaluates interdisciplinary research projects It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Foster research in the domain of sustainable development It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Brazil
heading: BELLA PROJECT
content:
Brazil's BELLA PROJECT (2017 - Ongoing). BELLA (Building the Europe Link with Latin America) provides for the long-term interconnectivity needs of European and Latin American research and education communities. It is an international cooperation initiative carried out by RNP, the Brazilian national research network, the RedClara, the Latin America regional research network and Géant, the European regional research network.
BELLA will achieve this through the procurement of a long-term Indefeasible Right of Use (IRU) for spectrum on a submarine cable between the two regions, minimising latency. BELLA is also developing and deploying a 100Gbps-capable research and education network across Latin America. It is part of the following theme(s): International co-operation, International STI governance policy, Ocean technology transfer and commercialisation, Research infrastructures, Support for public research, development and innovation. It has the following objective(s): The Project aims to promote the integration of Latin American and European research and innovation networks through a direct submarine fiber optic connection between both continents. The initiative also aims to expand the capacity of terrestrial connectivity within Latin America. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Brazil
heading: ATTO – AMAZON TALL TOWER OBSERVATORY
content: Brazil's ATTO – AMAZON TALL TOWER OBSERVATORY (2009 - Ongoing). The Amazon Tall Tower Observatory (ATTO) is a research site in the Amazon rainforest in Brazil in cooperation with Germany. On its center is a 325 m-tall steel guyed mast. In addition, it includes two further 80 m tall towers, as well as several container-laboratories and a base camp to accommodate scientists and technicians working there. Nearby field sites and study plots complete the site. It is part of the following theme(s): Mission-oriented innovation policies, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): Its aim is to continuously record meteorological, chemical and biological data, such as the concentration of greenhouses gases. With the help of these data, the goal is to learn more about biogeochemical cycles (such as the carbon cycle), the water cycle and energy fluxes in the Amazon. We want to determine their impact on global climate and how they are influenced by the changing climate. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Brazil
heading: AMAZÔNIA-1 SATELLITE
content: Brazil's AMAZÔNIA-1 SATELLITE (2013 - Ongoing). The Amazon Mission will provide remote sensing data (images) to observe and monitor deforestation, especially in the Amazon region, as well as the diversified agriculture throughout the country with a high revisit rate, working in synergy with existing environmental programs. It is part of the following theme(s): Mission-oriented innovation policies, Research infrastructures, Support for public R&D and infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): The data will be available to both the scientific community and government agencies and to users interested in a better understanding of the terrestrial environment. In Addition, the mission has an important technological objective: the validation of the PMM Multi Mission Platform as a system, which will be used for the first time in the Amazonia-1 satellite. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Bulgaria
heading: NATIONAL PROGRAMME "PETAR BERON AND NIE"
content: Bulgaria's NATIONAL PROGRAMME "PETAR BERON AND NIE" (2019 - Ongoing). The program stimulates the development of the research potential in Bulgaria as a necessary fundamental step for the creation of a sustainable scientific and innovation environment and for the development of a competitive high-tech economy in Bulgaria. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, High-risk high-reward research, Internationalisation in public research, Public research strategies. It has the following objective(s): attracting promising researchers with internationally recognized scientific results and supporting their rapid reintegration into Bulgarian higher education institutions and scientific organizations encouraging and facilitating intensive research on original and competitive topics, without limiting the ability to research and learn areas of interest (bottom up) It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Bulgaria
heading: EXCELLENT RESEARCH AND PEOPLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF EUROPEAN SCIENCE
content: Bulgaria's EXCELLENT RESEARCH AND PEOPLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF EUROPEAN SCIENCE (2019 - Ongoing). The National Scientific Program “Excellent Research and People for the Development of European Science” sets out the objectives and principles of funding, designed to support excellent Principal Investigators (PIs). In encompasses three Grant schemes. The leading researcher Grant scheme, The Established researcher Grant scheme, and frontier research grants. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, High-risk high-reward research, Internationalisation in public research. It has the following objective(s): Support research of ground-breaking nature that is feasible at the same time, on a bottom-up basis without predetermined priorities, with a focus on interdisciplinary approaches, which cross the boundaries between different fields of research, pioneering proposals addressing new and emerging fields of research or proposals introducing unconventional, innovative approaches and scientific inventions. to support excellent Principal Investigators at the career stage at which they are already established research leaders with a recognised track record of research achievements. to support excellent Principal Investigators at the career stage at which they are consolidating their own independent research team or program. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans, Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Spain
heading: Bioinformatics technical research support staff contracts at the IIS
content:
Spain's Bioinformatics technical research support staff contracts at the IIS (2018 - Ongoing). Grants to hire Bioinformaticians to work at Accredited Institutes of health to give supports to Clinical Research. Support the implementation of Bioinformatics techniques in the Clinical research. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): a) Optimize the available technological resources and benefit from the computational infrastructures offered by the ISCIII Data Science Platform.
b) Offer bioinformatics services to all IIS research groups. It uses Fellowships and postgraduate loans and scholarships as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: Portugal
heading: MOBILIZING R&D FOR FOREST FIRE PREVENTION AND CONTROL
content: Portugal's MOBILIZING R&D FOR FOREST FIRE PREVENTION AND CONTROL (2017 - Ongoing). R&D program created by the Resolution of the Council of Ministers no. 159/2017 of 21 October, following the recommendations of the report of the Independent Technical Commission that investigated the "Pedrógão Grande fires". It is part of the following theme(s): Cross-disciplinary research. It has the following objective(s): Enhance the development of R&D activities to encourage and strengthen skills and scientific and technological capabilities ensure ownership and scientific knowledge incorporation in decision support in operating systems facilitate the production of new knowledge oriented to the solution of concrete and real problems It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Hungary
heading: NATIONAL LABORATORIES PROGRAMME
content: Hungary's NATIONAL LABORATORIES PROGRAMME (2020 - Ongoing). National Laboratories are dynamic, institutionalizing, collaboration-based arenas of discovery and experimental research that open up new, international dimensions and enable the social, economic and environmental utilisation of research results. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Cross-disciplinary research, Mission-oriented innovation policies, Non-competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Launching new mission-oriented flagship programs of internationally recognized quality within the budget of the National Research, Development and Innovation Office (National Laboratories), in line with the objectives of the Research, Development and Innovation Strategy, by expanding its R&D, innovation and innovation funding programs. Concentrate domestic professional workshops in specific research fields; Develop competencies necessary for addressing major global issues at the international level Utilise research results for social, economic and environmental purposes (knowledge transfer) It uses Project grants for public research, Dedicated support to research infrastructures, Centres of excellence grants as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Türkiye
heading: TUBITAK 1000 - SUPPORT PROGRAMME FOR IMPROVEMENT OF R&D CAPACITY OF UNIVERSITIES
content: Türkiye's TUBITAK 1000 - SUPPORT PROGRAMME FOR IMPROVEMENT OF R&D CAPACITY OF UNIVERSITIES (2015 - Ongoing). The program provides financial support to universities for increasing their R&D capacity by dedicated calls with specific strategic objectives. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding, Structural change of the public research system. It has the following objective(s): To promote universities for taking actions in order to increase their R&D capacity To aid smart specialisation in universities. It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of Less than 1M euros.

title: United Kingdom
heading: EXPANDING EXCELLENCE IN ENGLAND FUND
content: United Kingdom's EXPANDING EXCELLENCE IN ENGLAND FUND (2019 - Ongoing). The Expanding Excellence in England (E3) fund aims to support the strategic expansion of excellent research units and departments in HEIs across England. In order to expand excellence, E3 focuses only on units and departments where there is demonstrable research excellence already, but limited scale of activity. This is a competitive scheme and £75m is available through the fund to be allocated to each successful unit/department over three years (AY 19/20, 20/21 and 21/22). Awards will be for the three year period, allowing successful bidders time to scale up activity and build quality. It is part of the following theme(s): Collaborative research and innovation, Commercialisation of public research results, Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): Strengthen the contribution of English HEIs to our society, pushing the frontiers of human knowledge, delivering economic impact and creating social impact by supporting our society and others to become enriched, healthier, more resilient and sustainable Build the capacity and quality of research in departments and units within English universities where excellence exists but at a small scale with potential for growth; Enhance the skills base and build talent in areas of research excellence where there is untapped potential Stimulate strategic partnerships between HEIs and other organisations outside of Higher Education. It uses Dedicated support to research infrastructures as policy instruments.

title: United Kingdom
heading: NETWORKS IN INDUSTRIAL BIOTECHNOLOGY AND BIOENERGY PHASE II
content: United Kingdom's NETWORKS IN INDUSTRIAL BIOTECHNOLOGY AND BIOENERGY PHASE II (2019 - Ongoing). Building capacity and capability in the UK supporting research and translation in sustainable, biologically based manufacturing through collaboration between academic researchers and businesses at all levels. It is part of the following theme(s): High-risk high-reward research. It has the following objective(s): Drive new ideas to harness the potential of biological resources for producing and processing materials, biopharmaceuticals, chemicals and energy. It uses Institutional funding for public research as policy instruments. and it has a budget of 1M-5M euros.

title: Japan
heading: FUNDING FROM THE JAPAN SOCIETY FOR THE PROMOTION OF SCIENCE
content: Japan's FUNDING FROM THE JAPAN SOCIETY FOR THE PROMOTION OF SCIENCE (1932 - Ongoing). Funding from the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), or Gakushin for short contributes to advancements in all fields of the natural and social sciences and the humanities. It is part of the following theme(s): Competitive research funding. It has the following objective(s): To foster young researchers To promote international scientific cooperation To award Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research To support scientific cooperation between the academic community and industry To collect and distribute information on scientific research activities It uses Project grants for public research as policy instruments.

title: United Kingdom
heading: 2020 VISION FOR SCIENCE AND RESEARCH - LONG TERM CAPITAL INVESTMENT
content: United Kingdom's 2020 VISION FOR SCIENCE AND RESEARCH - LONG TERM CAPITAL INVESTMENT (2014 - Ongoing). Roadmap for UK Government capital investment in world-class science and research infrastructure It is part of the following theme(s): Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): To set out strategic priorities for long-term science and research capital investment. It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: South Africa
heading: WHITE PAPER ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION
content: South Africa's WHITE PAPER ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION (2019 - Ongoing). White Paper on Science, Technology and Innovation (2019) emphasises the core themes of inclusivity, transformation, and partnerships. Proposals are made to address policy coherence, the development of human capabilities, knowledge expansion, innovation performance and increased investment. It is part of the following theme(s): Business innovation policy strategies, Cross-disciplinary research, Public research strategies, Research and innovation for society strategy, STI human resources strategies, STI plan or strategy, Structural change of the public research system, Transfer and linkages strategies. It has the following objective(s): Improved coherence and coordination Increased NSI partnering between business, academia, government and civil society Strengthened and transformed NSI institutions Increased human capabilities Expanded research enterprise Enhanced enabling environment for innovation It uses Strategies, agendas and plans as policy instruments.

title: South Africa
heading: SOUTH AFRICAN RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE ROAD MAP
content: South Africa's SOUTH AFRICAN RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE ROAD MAP (2016 - Ongoing). South African Research Infrastructure Roadmap (SARIR) framework was developed as the basis for prioritising the development of national research infrastructure needs. SARIR is a high-level strategic and systemic intervention to provide research infrastructure across the entire public research system, building on existing capabilities and strengths, and drawing on future needs. It is part of the following theme(s): International STI governance policy, Public research strategies, Research and innovation for society strategy, Research infrastructures. It has the following objective(s): This roadmap will provide guidance to the Department of Science and Technology (DST) on the strategic development, acquisition and deployment of research infrastructure as a necessary enabler for research, development and innovation.
